nationalteam-update = 18:35, 6 May 2018 (UTC) }} '''Alexandre Lacazette''' ({{IPA-fr|alɛksɑ̃dʁ lakazɛt}}; born 28 May 1991) is a French professional [[association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Forward (association football)|forward]] for {{English football updater|Arsenal}} club [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] and the [[France national football team|France national team]].
Lacazette came into prominence as a member of the academy at [[Olympique Lyonnais|Lyon]], where he made his professional debut aged 19. He helped the club win the [[2012 Coupe de France Final|Coupe de France]] and [[2012 Trophée des Champions|Trophée des Champions]] in 2012, and was named the [[Trophées UNFP du football#Player of the Year|Ligue 1 Player of the Year]] in [[2014–15 Ligue 1|2014–15]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Crossan|first1=D.|title=LACAZETTE NETS HAT-TRICK AS OL WALLOP LILLE|url=http://www.ligue1.com/ligue1/article/lacazette-nets-first-hat-trick-as-ol-wallop-lille.htm|accessdate=22 December 2014|publisher=[[Ligue 1]]|date=5 October 2014}}</ref> During his time in France, Lacazette cultivated a reputation as a prolific goalscorer and poacher, recording multiple twenty-goal seasons, which earned him a move to [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] in a then club-record £46.5 million (€53 million) deal in 2017.<ref name="Arsenal F.C">{{cite press release|url=https://www.arsenal.com/news/alexandre-lacazette-agrees-join-arsenal|title= Alexandre Lacazette agrees to join Arsenal |date=5 July 2017|access-date=6 July 2017|website=arsenal.com|publisher=Arsenal F.C.}}</ref>
Ever since debuting for the national side, Lacazette has represented France across all youth levels. He was a key player in France's victory in the [[2010 UEFA European Under-19 Championship]], where he scored the match-winning goal in the final against Spain.<ref name="ESPN FC">{{cite web|title=France calls on Alexandre Lacazette|url=http://www.espnfc.com/story/1457666/france-subs-in-alexandre-lacazette-for-injured-jeremy-menez|publisher=ESPN FC|accessdate=11 August 2014|date=23 May 2013}}</ref> He then made his senior international debut in June 2013, scoring his first goal in March 2015.
Known for dribbling, pace, and ability with both feet, as well as his persistence to press and tackle when out of possession, Lacazette has been compared to former Arsenal forward [[Ian Wright]] by [[Gérard Houllier]].<ref name="metro.co.uk">{{cite web|url=http://metro.co.uk/2017/07/05/arsenal-transfer-target-alexandre-lacazette-is-like-ian-wright-says-gerard-houllier-6757159/|title=Alexandre Lacazette is like Ian Wright, says Gerard Houllier|website=Metro.co.uk}}</ref>
==Early life== Alexandre Lacazette was born in [[Lyon]] on 28 May 1991 to a family of [[Guadeloupe]]an origin. He is the youngest of four boys. One of his brothers, Benoît, played in the [[Swiss Challenge League|Swiss second division]] and [[Championnat de France Amateur|French fourth division]] and was the coach in the Lyon [[futsal]] club: Lyon Footzik Futsal. His cousin, [[Romuald Lacazette|Romuald]], is also a professional footballer and plays as a central midfielder.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.lequipe.fr/Football/Actualites/Romuald-lacazette-s-engage-a-darmstadt-pour-trois-ans/812689|title= Romuald Lacazette s'engage à Darmstadt pour trois ans|trans-title= Romuald Lacazette commits to Darmstadt for three years|language=French|date=22 June 2017| publisher=L'Équipe}}</ref> Lacazette started playing football at the age of seven for his local club Elan Sportif, in the [[8th arrondissement of Lyon]].{{Citation needed|date=January 2018}}
==Club career== ===Lyon=== ====Youth and reserve teams==== Upon his arrival at the club, Lacazette began training at the [[Centre Tola Vologe]], the club's training center. While undergoing training, he was likened to former Lyon striker [[Sonny Anderson]] by many coaches, including the player himself.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.leprogres.fr/fr/permalien/article/3093043/Les-debuts-d-Alexandre-Lacazette.html | publisher=Le Progrès | title = Les débuts d'Alexandre Lacazette |language = French |date = 6 May 2010 | accessdate = 5 November 2010}}{{dead link|date=October 2015}}</ref> As a youth player, Lacazette played in the club's under-18 team that finished in third place in the ''Championnat National des moins de 18 ans'' during the 2007–08 season. The [[2008–09 Championnat de France Amateur|following season]], he began making appearances for the club's [[Championnat de France amateur|Championnat de France amateur (CFA)]] reserve team, netting 5 goals in 19 [[Championnat de France amateur|Championnat de France amateur (CFA)]] matches.<ref name ="lacazette_national">{{Cite web| url = http://www.foot-national.com/4377-joueur-football-Lacazette-Alexandre.html | title = Statistiques détaillées de Alexandre Lacazette| accessdate = 5 November 2009 | publisher=Foot-National}}</ref> In the [[2009–10 Championnat de France Amateur|2009–10 season]], Lacazette had a stellar campaign in the CFA, scoring 12 goals in 22 appearances.<ref name ="lacazette_national"/>
====2009–10 season==== During the second half of the [[2009–10 Ligue 1]] season, he was called up to the first team by manager [[Claude Puel]] and appeared on the bench in the team's 1–0 victory over [[Montpellier HSC|Montpellier]] on 2 May 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://new.lfp.fr/ligue1/feuille_match/45019 |publisher=[[Ligue de Football Professionnel]] |title=Montpellier v. Lyon Match Report |language=French |date=2 May 2010 |accessdate=5 November 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120313204035/http://new.lfp.fr/ligue1/feuille_match/45019 |archivedate=13 March 2012 }}</ref> Three days later, Lacazette made his first team debut in a Ligue 1 home match against [[AJ Auxerre|Auxerre]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://new.lfp.fr/ligue1/feuille_match/44957 |publisher=[[Ligue de Football Professionnel]] |title=Lyon v. Auxerre Match Report |language=French |date=5 May 2010 |accessdate=5 November 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120313204107/http://new.lfp.fr/ligue1/feuille_match/44957 |archivedate=13 March 2012 |df=dmy }}</ref> On 3 July 2010, Lacazette signed his first professional contract agreeing to a three-year deal. Due to still having another year left on his ''aspirant'' (youth) contract, the contract would start on 1 July 2011.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.francefootball.fr/FF/breves2010/20100703_145617_lacazette-passe-pro-dans-un-an.html | publisher = [[France Football]] | title = Lacazette passe pro... dans un an | language = French | date = 3 July 2010 | accessdate = 3 July 2010 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20100704200916/http://www.francefootball.fr/FF/breves2010/20100703_145617_lacazette-passe-pro-dans-un-an.html | archivedate = 4 July 2010 | deadurl = yes | df = dmy-all }}</ref> [[File:2013-03-03 Match Brest-OL - Lacazette (2).JPG|thumb|left|250px|upright|Lacazette with Lyon in 2013]]
====2010–11 season==== Lacazette's successful campaign in the [[2010 UEFA European Under-19 Championship]] saw the player draw interest from Italian club [[A.S. Roma|Roma]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.maxifoot.fr/football-rss120639/lyon-lacazette.php|publisher=Maxifoot.fr|title=Lyon : Lacazette ne partira pas|language=French|date=2 August 2010}}</ref> He also drew praise from the media, alongside international teammates [[Yannis Tafer]] and [[Clément Grenier]], for his dedication to the club after playing in the pre-season [[2010 Emirates Cup]] match hours by playing in the final of the [[2010 UEFA European Under-19 Football Championship]].<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.goal.com/en/news/3358/uefa-european-under-19-championships/2010/08/02/2052505/the-epitome-of-dedication-how-france-under-19-hero-alexandre | publisher=Goal.com | title = The Epitome of Dedication? How France Under-19 Hero Alexandre Lacazette Played Three Matches in Three Days |date = 2 August 2010 | accessdate = 5 November 2010}}</ref> Lacazette began the [[2010–11 in French football|2010–11 season]] training full-time with the first team. He scored 6 goals in 12 [[2010–11 Championnat de France Amateur|2010–11 CFA]] matches for the club's reserve team.<ref name ="lacazette_national"/> He scored his first competitive goal for the first team on 30 October in a Ligue 1 home match against [[FC Sochaux-Montbéliard|Sochaux]].<ref name="lacazette_football">{{cite web|url=http://www.football.fr/lyon/articles/alexandre-lacazette-debute-sa-carriere-sous-les-meilleures-auspices-297335/|title=L'heure de Lacazette|date=3 November 2010|accessdate=5 November 2009|publisher=Football.fr}}</ref> His goal in the 69th minute gave Lyon a 2–1 lead, which would be the final score.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://new.lfp.fr/ligue1/feuille_match/53732 |publisher=[[Ligue de Football Professionnel]] |title=Lyon v. Sochaux Match Report |language=French |date=31 October 2010 |accessdate=5 November 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101102150951/http://new.lfp.fr/ligue1/feuille_match/53732 |archivedate=2 November 2010 |deadurl=yes }}</ref> Three days later, Lacazette made his [[UEFA competitions|European club competition]] debut against the Portuguese club [[S.L. Benfica|Benfica]] in a [[2010–11 UEFA Champions League group stage|2010–11 UEFA Champions League]] Group B away match, appearing as a substitute in the second half with Lyon trailing 4–0. Minutes after coming onto the pitch, he [[assist (football)|assisted]] Lyon's opening goal, scored by [[Yoann Gourcuff]] in the 75th minute. He also assisted Lyon's second goal, scored by [[Bafétimbi Gomis]] in the 85th minute.<ref name ="lacazette_football"/> Lyon, however, were unable to complete the comeback, losing 4–3.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.uefa.com/uefachampionsleague/matches/season=2011/round=2000118/match=2002876/index.html |publisher=[[UEFA|Union of European Football Associations]] |title=Coentrão inspires Benfica revival |date=2 November 2010 |accessdate=5 November 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101105010750/http://www.uefa.com/uefachampionsleague/matches/season%3D2011/round%3D2000118/match%3D2002876/index.html |archivedate=5 November 2010 }}</ref> On 7 December, Lacazette scored the first European club competition goal of his career in Lyon's final Group B match, the 88th-minute equalizer in the 2–2 home draw against Israeli club [[Hapoel Tel Aviv F.C.|Hapoel Tel Aviv]].
====2011–16 seasons==== [[File:Zenit-Lion15 (5).jpg|thumb|150px|Lacazette playing for Lyon in 2015]] Lacazette scored Lyon's only goal in the [[2014 Coupe de la Ligue Final]] against Paris Saint-Germain; however his side lost 2–1.<ref>{{cite news|title=Paris St-Germain v Lyon as it happened|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/27090265|accessdate=21 April 2014|newspaper=[[Sky Sports News]]|date=19 April 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140421070721/http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/27090265|archive-date=21 April 2014|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
In September 2014, Lacazette signed a two-year extension to his contract, tying him to the club until 2018.<ref>{{cite web|title=Alexandre Lacazette signs two-year contract extension with Lyon|url=http://www.espnfc.com/french-ligue-1/story/2030874/alexandre-lacazette-signs-contract-extension-with-lyon|publisher=ESPN FC|accessdate=13 September 2014|date=11 September 2014}}</ref> He scored his first hat-trick on 5 October 2014, netting all the goals in a 3–0 Ligue 1 home win over [[Lille OSC|Lille]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Crossan|first1=D.|title=LACAZETTE NETS FIRST HAT-TRICK AS OL WALLOP LILLE|url=http://www.ligue1.com/ligue1/article/lacazette-nets-first-hat-trick-as-ol-wallop-lille.htm|accessdate=22 December 2014|publisher=[[Ligue 1]]|date=5 October 2014}}</ref> On 26 April 2015, Lacazette broke the Lyon record for [[Ligue 1|Ligue 1 or Division 1]] goals scored in a single season with his 26th in a Ligue 1 4–2 away victory over [[Stade de Reims|Reims]]; [[André Guy]] had scored a total of 25 Division 1 goals in the [[1968–69 French Division 1|1968–69 season]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.olweb.fr/en/article/ol-keep-hat-in-the-ring-67957.html|title=OL KEEP HAT IN THE RING|website=OL Web.fr}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eurosport.fr/football/ligue-1/2014-2015/lyon-alexandre-lacazette-egale-andre-guy-avec-25-buts-en-ligue-1-cette-saison_sto4679046/story.shtml|title=Lyon : Alexandre Lacazette égale André Guy avec 25 buts en Ligue 1 cette saison|website=Eurosport|date=15 April 2015}}</ref> He finished the [[2014–15 Ligue 1]] season as the top scorer in Ligue 1, netting a total of 27 goals.<ref name="lg1">{{cite web|title=Official top scorer chart 2014–15|url=http://www.ligue1.com/ligue1/classementButeurs#sai=83&journee1=1&journee2=38&cat=G&poste=Tous|website=Lique 1|accessdate=9 July 2015}}</ref> Lacazette completed an outstanding season by being voted [[Ligue 1 Player of the Year]] for the 2014–15 season.<ref name="poy">{{cite web|title=Lacazette wins player of the year|url=http://www.ligue1.com/ligue1/article/lacazette-wins-player-of-year.htm|website=Lique 1|accessdate=9 July 2015|date=18 May 2015}}</ref>
Amid transfer speculation from a number of [[Premier League]] clubs such as [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] following his breakout season, on 8 August 2015, Lacazette signed a new deal, extending his contract with Lyon until 2019.<ref>{{cite web|title=Alexandre Lacazette signs new contract with Lyon through to 2019|url=http://www.espnfc.com.ve/story/2552588/alexandre-lacazette-signs-new-contract-with-lyon|publisher=[[ESPN FC]]|accessdate=8 August 2015|date=8 August 2015}}</ref> On 8 November 2015, he scored all of the goals in a 3–0 Ligue 1 home win over [[Derby du Rhone|local arch-rivals]] [[AS Saint-Étienne|Saint-Étienne]].<ref>{{cite news|title='I felt that Alexandre Lacazette was coming good': Lyon inspired by striker over Saint-Etienne|url=http://www.thenational.ae/sport/ligue-1/i-felt-that-alexandre-lacazette-was-coming-good-lyon-inspired-by-striker-over-saint-etienne|accessdate=4 April 2016|publisher=The National|date=8 November 2015}}</ref> On 9 January 2016, he scored the first goal at the newly opened [[Parc Olympique Lyonnais]], in a 4–1 win over [[Troyes AC|Troyes]] in a Ligue 1 match.<ref>{{cite news|title=Lyon 4–1 Troyes: Alexandre Lacazette nets as Ligue 1 giants celebrate opening of their new Parc OL stadium in style|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-3392213/Lyon-4-1-Troyes-Alexandre-Lacazette-nets-Ligue-1-giants-celebrate-opening-new-Parc-OL-stadium-style.html|accessdate=4 April 2016|work=Daily Mail|date=10 January 2016}}</ref>
====2016–17 season==== On 29 October 2016, Lacazette scored two goals in Lyon's 2–1 away win against [[Toulouse FC|Toulouse]] in Ligue 1 to register his 100th and 101st goals in all competitions for Lyon, overtaking [[Juninho Pernambucano]] (who scored 100 goals in 350 competitive matches for Lyon) to become the fourth-most prolific scorer in Lyon's history.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ligue1.com/ligue1/article/lacazette-at-the-double-as-ol-score-valuable-win.htm|title=Lacazette at the double as OL score valuable win|publisher=www.ligue1.com|date=29 October 2016}}</ref> On 22 November, he scored the only goal by slotting home [[Rafael (footballer, born 1990)|Rafael]]'s rolled cross from close range in the 72nd minute of the [[2016–17 UEFA Champions League group stage]] Group H matchday 5 1–0 away win against [[GNK Dinamo Zagreb|Dinamo Zagreb]] to keep alive Lyon's hopes of progressing to the knockout phase of the 2016–17 UEFA Champions League.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.espnfc.com/report?gameId=466192|title=Alexandre Lacazette fires Lyon to victory over Dinamo Zagreb|publisher=ESPN FC|date=22 November 2016}}</ref>
In early February 2017, Lacazette reportedly revealed to television show Canal Football Club his intention to leave Olympique Lyonnais in the summer of 2017. On 10 February, [[Jean-Michel Aulas]], the club's president, denied that Lacazette had asked to leave that summer and said that Lacazette's comments were taken out of context by the media.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://talksport.com/football/lyon-president-jean-michel-aulas-plays-down-alexandre-lacazette-exit-talk-arsenal-and-west|title=Lyon president Jean-Michel Aulas plays down Alexandre Lacazette exit talk as Arsenal and West Ham eye deal|publisher=Talksport|date=10 February 2017}}</ref>
===Arsenal=== ====Transfer==== On 5 July 2017, Lacazette signed a reported five-year deal for Premier League club Arsenal for a club record fee;<ref name="Arsenal F.C"/><ref name=BBC/> Lyon disclosed that the fee was an initial €53 million (£46.5 million) plus up to €7 million (£6.1 million) in potential bonuses.<ref name=BBC/><ref name="Lyonpress"/> The fee was the largest ever received by Lyon from the sale of a player, beating the €41.5 million (£37.7 million) record set by [[Corentin Tolisso]]'s transfer to [[FC Bayern Munich|Bayern Munich]] three weeks earlier.<ref name="Lyonpress">{{cite press release|url=https://www.actusnews.com/documents_communiques/ACTUS-0-49376-olg-050717-cession-a-lacazette-arsenal-gb.pdf|title=Transfer of Alexandre Lacazette to Arsenal|date=5 July 2017|access-date=6 July 2017|publisher=Olympique Lyonnais Group}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Communiqué : Transfert de Corentin Tolisso au Bayern Munich {{!}} OLWeb.fr|url=http://www.olweb.fr/fr/article/communique-transfert-de-corentin-tolisso-au-bayern-munich-31268.html|publisher=Olympique Lyon|language=fr-FR}}</ref> The transfer fee also surpassed the previous Arsenal record €50 million (£42.5 million) that Arsenal paid [[Real Madrid C.F.|Real Madrid]] for [[Mesut Özil]] in 2013.<ref name=BBC>{{cite news |title=Alexandre Lacazette joins Arsenal for club record £46.5m from Lyon |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/40496970 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=5 July 2017 |accessdate=5 July 2017 }}</ref>
On May 2017, it was reported that a verbal arrangement had been reached for Lacazette to join [[Atlético Madrid]] in the summer of 2017, but that fell through on 1 June 2017, after the [[Court of Arbitration for Sport]] upheld Atlético's ban on registering players for two [[transfer window]]s (1 January – 2 February 2017 and 1 June – 31 August 2017) that was imposed in July 2016 by [[FIFA]] on the club for breaching [[FIFA]] rules over the signing of minors. Lacazette was given the number 9 jersey.<ref>{{cite news |title=Alexandre Lacazette agrees to join Atletico Madrid from Lyon subject to transfer ban|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11095/10886538/alexandre-lacazette-agrees-to-join-atletico-madrid-from-lyon-subject-to-transfer-ban|publisher=Sky Sports|date=21 May 2017|accessdate=6 July 2017 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Atletico Madrid transfer ban upheld by Court of Arbitration for Sport|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/40117879|publisher=BBC Sport|date=1 June 2017 |accessdate=6 July 2017 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Alexandre Lacazette's failed Atletico move 'good and bad' for Lyon – Aulas|url=http://www.espnfcasia.com/story/3137721/alexandre-lacazettes-failed-atletico-madrid-move-good-and-bad-for-lyon-aulas|publisher=ESPN FC|date=2 June 2017 |accessdate=6 July 2017 }}</ref><ref>{{cite press release|url=http://beta.goal.com/en/news/lacazette-takes-arsenal-no9-shirt-as-gunners-reveal-new/djconbb0ccdo12ayufn5265ol|title= LACAZETTE TAKES ARSENAL NO.9 SHIRT |date=11 July 2017|access-date=11 July 2017|website=goal.com}}</ref>
====2017–18 season==== [[File:Alexandre Lacazette 2018 May.jpg|thumb|upright|Lacazette playing for Arsenal in 2018]] On 6 August 2017, Lacazette made his first appearance for Arsenal in the [[2017 FA Community Shield]] against [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]]. Despite hitting the post midway through the first half, Arsenal eventually won 4–1 on penalties after the game ended 1–1 at full time. This win constituted his first trophy win at Arsenal.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/news/arsenal-chelsea-community-live-score-10939633|title=Arsenal vs. Chelsea: Live score and goal updates from Community Shield|last=Prenderville|first=Liam|work=Mirror|access-date=10 August 2017}}</ref> On 11 August, Lacazette made his Premier League debut against [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]] and scored after 94 seconds to give Arsenal a 1–0 lead in an eventual 4–3 win.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/40822513|title=Arsenal 4–3 Leicester City|last=Jurejko|first=Jonathan|work=[[BBC Sport]]|access-date=11 August 2017}}</ref> Lacazette also managed to score in both of Arsenal's next home games, scoring Arsenal's second in a 3–0 win over [[A.F.C. Bournemouth|Bournemouth]], before grabbing a brace for the club in a 2–0 win over [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]].<ref>{{citeweb|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/41133353|title=Arsenal 3–0 Bournemouth|last=Davis|first=Matt|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=9 September 2017}}</ref> With his goals against West Brom, Lacazette became the first Arsenal player to score in his first three home league appearances for the club since [[Brian Marwood]] in September 1988.<ref>{{citeweb|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/41302628|title=Arsenal 2–0 West Brom|last=Henry|first=Matthew|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=25 September 2017}}</ref>
Lacazette scored his first away goal for Arsenal, in the team's 5–2 win against Everton at Goodison Park, latching onto a pass from [[Mesut Özil]], to score Arsenal's third.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/41625741|title=Everton 2–5 Arsenal|date=22 October 2017|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> Lacazette claimed his 6th goal of the season in Arsenal's 3–1 away defeat to [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] after latching onto an [[Aaron Ramsey]] pass, despite not starting the game.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/41792812|title=Manchester City 3–1 Arsenal|date=5 November 2017|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> In November, Lacazette scored Arsenal's opening goal in a 5–0 rout of [[Huddersfield Town A.F.C.|Huddersfield Town]] and in December, he scored Arsenal's only goal in a 3–1 home defeat to [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/42075942|title=Arsenal 5–0 Huddersfield Town|website=BBC.co.uk}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/42119930|title=Arsenal 1–3 Manchester United|date=2 December 2017|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref>
Following a protracted period on the sidelines through injury, Lacazette returned to the Arsenal squad in the 3–0 home win over [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke City]] in March, where he replaced [[Danny Welbeck]] in the 61st minute and scored the Gunners' third goal of the game, after new signing and designated penalty-taker [[Pierre-Emerick Aubameyang]], allowed Lacazette to take the penalty.<ref>{{citeweb|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/43530417|title=Arsenal 3–0 Stoke City|website=BBC.co.uk}}</ref> Lacazette would then score twice on his Europa League debut for Arsenal, in a 4–1 win against [[PFC CSKA Moscow|CSKA Moscow]], marking his first goal in European competition for the club.<ref>{{citeweb|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/43632183|title=Arsenal 4–1 CSKA Moscow|website=BBC.co.uk}}</ref> Lacazette then registered his third goal in European football for Arsenal, by scoring in the Europa League semi-final 1–1 draw with Atlético Madrid. The goal was Lacazette's seventh goal in seven games for the club since returning from injury.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/43915785|title=Arsenal 1–1 Atletico Madrid: Arsene Wenger says worst result for Arsenal|date=2018-04-26|work=BBC Sport|access-date=2018-06-04|language=en-GB}}</ref> Lacazette scored in [[Arsène Wenger]]'s final home match, a 5–0 rout of [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]], the team's second goal and his fourteenth league goal of the season, Lacazette also picked up an assist for the team's opening goal as well.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/43939015|title=Arsenal 5–0 Burnley|date=2018-05-06|work=BBC Sport|access-date=2018-06-04|language=en-GB}}</ref>
====2018–19 season==== After the departure of manager Arsène Wenger, Lacazette found himself dropped to the bench under new manager [[Unai Emery]], making substitute appearances against [[Manchester City]], [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] and West Ham.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/45138012|title=Arsenal 0-2 Man City: Unai Emery's opener is a reality check for Arsenal|date=12 August 2018|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/45236243|title=Chelsea 3-2 Arsenal: 'Chaotic classic exposes both sides' title limitations'|date=18 August 2018|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/45230637|title=Arsenal 3-1 West Ham United: Unai Emery secures first win as Gunners boss|date=25 August 2018|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> Lacazette made his first start under Emery in Arsenal's 3–2 away win over [[Cardiff City]] on September 2, where he registered an assist and scored his first goal of the season.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/45312124|title=Cardiff 2-3 Arsenal: Gunners win through Alexandre Lacazette's late strike|date=2 September 2018|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref>
==International career== ===Youth=== Lacazette has featured for all of [[France national youth football team|France's national youth teams]] beginning with the [[France national under-16 football team|under-16 team]] making his debut in the team's 2–0 victory over [[Cameroon national football team|Cameroon]] on 3 April 2007 at the [[Montaigu Tournament]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Débuts réussis pour la France (2–0)|url=http://www.fff.fr///selections/m16ans/actualite/369431.shtml |work=[[French Football Federation]]|date=3 April 2007 |accessdate=5 November 2010| language = French}}</ref> He finished the campaign with four appearances in the tournament. With the [[France national under-17 football team|under-17 team]], Lacazette was a regular and contributed to the team's qualification for the [[2008 UEFA European Under-17 Football Championship]]. In the competition, he scored the game-winning goal in the team's 2–1 win over the [[Republic of Ireland national under-17 football team|Republic of Ireland]] in the group stage.<ref>{{cite news|title=France sweat their way to glory |url=http://www.uefa.com/news/newsid=691701.html|work=[[UEFA|Union of European Football Associations]] |date=4 May 2008 |accessdate=5 November 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Entrée en matière réussie (2–1)|url=http://www.fff.fr/selections/m17ans/actualite/439252.shtml |publisher=[[French Football Federation]]|date=4 May 2008|accessdate=5 November 2010}}</ref> France later reached the final where the team was defeated 4–0 by [[Spain national under-17 football team|Spain]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Stupendous Spain win U17 crown |url=http://en.archive.uefa.com/competitions/under17/fixturesresults/round=15032/match=302551/report=rp.html |work=[[UEFA|Union of European Football Associations]] |date=16 May 2008 |accessdate=5 November 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120630012630/http://en.archive.uefa.com/competitions/under17/fixturesresults/round=15032/match=302551/report=rp.html |archivedate=30 June 2012 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=L'Espagne réalise le doublé|url=http://www.fff.fr/selections/m17ans/actualite/441710.shtml |publisher=[[French Football Federation]] |date=16 May 2008|accessdate=5 November 2010}}</ref>
[[File:Alexandre Lacazette.jpg|thumb|Lacazette playing for the [[France national under-21 football team|Les Bleuets]] in a game against Kazakhstan in [[Clermont-Ferrand]], October 2011.]] With the [[France national under-18 football team|under-18 team]], Lacazette made his debut in the team's match against [[Ukraine national under-18 football team|Ukraine]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Défaite pour les Tricolores (1–3)|url=http://www.fff.fr/selections/m18ans/actualite/466233.shtml |publisher=[[French Football Federation]] |date=30 September 2008 |accessdate=5 November 2010| language = French}}</ref> He featured in ten of the eleven matches the team contested scoring one goal, which came against [[Denmark national under-18 football team|Denmark]] in the Tournoi de Limoges.<ref>{{cite news |title=France et Danemark dos à dos (1–1)|url=http://www.fff.fr/selections/m18ans/actualite/473096.shtml |publisher=[[French Football Federation]] |date=28 October 2008 |accessdate=5 November 2010| language = French}}</ref> For [[France national under-19 football team|under-19 duty]], Lacazette was again called upon by coach [[Francis Smerecki]], making his first appearance for the team in a 4–2 defeat against [[Netherlands national under-19 football team|Netherlands]] on 9 November 2009.<ref>{{cite news |title= Pays-Bas 4–2 France |url=http://www.fff.fr/servfff/fiche_joueur_new/match.php?id_match=132 |publisher=[[French Football Federation]] |date=9 November 2009|accessdate=5 November 2010}}</ref> He scored his first goal for the team on 4 March 2010 in a 2–1 win against [[Ukraine national under-19 football team|Ukraine]].<ref>{{cite news |title= France 2–1 Ukraine |url=http://www.fff.fr/servfff/fiche_joueur_new/match.php?id_match=187 |publisher=[[French Football Federation]] |date=4 March 2010|accessdate=5 November 2010}}</ref> On 7 June 2010, Lacazette was named to coach Smerecki's 18-man squad to participate in the [[2010 UEFA European Under-19 Championship]]. In the tournament, he scored two goals in the team's 5–0 Group A victory over [[Austria national under-19 football team|Austria]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.uefa.com/under19/matches/season=2010/round=15348/match=2002379/index.html |title=Flowing France leave Austria reeling |publisher=[[UEFA|Union of European Football Associations]] |date=21 July 2010 |accessdate=5 November 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100723013848/http://www.uefa.com/under19/matches/season%3D2010/round%3D15348/match%3D2002379/index.html |archivedate=23 July 2010 }}</ref> France later reached the final where they faced [[Spain national under-19 football team|Spain]], which was essentially composed of the same players that defeated France in the 2008 UEFA European Under-17 Football Championship final. In the match, France came back from a goal down to win 2–1 with Lacazette netting the game-winning goal in the 85th minute after heading in a cross from [[Gaël Kakuta]]. France thus secured their second UEFA European Under-19 championship title.<ref name="fu19">{{cite news|url=http://www.uefa.com/news/newsid=1508904.html|title=France fight back to claim U19 crown|publisher=[[UEFA|Union of European Football Associations]]|date=30 July 2010|accessdate=5 August 2010}}</ref>
Due to France's victory at the 2010 UEFA European Under-19 championship, the nation qualified for the [[2011 FIFA U-20 World Cup]]. This resulted in Lacazette making appearances for the [[France national under-20 football team|under-20 team]]. He made his under-20 team debut on 7 October 2010 in a [[Exhibition match|friendly match]] against [[Portugal national under-20 football team|Portugal]]. The match ended 3–3 with Lacazette scoring the opening goal of the match.<ref>{{cite news |title= France 3–3 Portugal |url=http://www.fff.fr/servfff/fiche_joueur_new/match.php?id_match=1320 |publisher=[[French Football Federation]] |date=7 October 2010|accessdate=5 November 2010}}</ref> Three days later, Lacazette scored a double in the team's 5–0 thrashing of the [[Juventus F.C. Youth Sector|Juventus Primavera]] team.<ref>{{cite news |title= Festival offensif à Chambéry (5–0) |url=http://www.fff.fr/selections/20ans/actualite/535249.shtml |publisher=[[French Football Federation]] |date=10 October 2010|accessdate=5 November 2010}}</ref> The match was unofficial and was contested as part of the celebration of the [[Savoy#Annexation to France|Treaty of Turin]]. On 9 February 2011, Lacazette scored the game-winning goal in a 2–1 victory over [[England national under-20 football team|England]]. In March 2011, Lacazette scored goals in back-to-back matches against [[Peru national under-20 football team|Peru]].
On 10 June 2011, he was named to the 21-man squad to participate in the [[2011 FIFA U-20 World Cup]] finals. He made his debut in the competition in France's first Group A match on 30 July 2011 against the host nation [[Colombia national under-20 football team|Colombia]] (France lost the match 4–1), appearing as a substitute.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.fifa.com/u20worldcup/matches/round=255641/match=300145857/index.html | publisher=[[FIFA|Fédération Internationale de Football Association]] | title = Colombia 4–1 France |date = 30 July 2011 | accessdate = 2 August 2011 }}</ref> In the team's next Group A match against [[South Korea national under-20 football team|South Korea]], Lacazette appeared as a substitute again and scored the final goal (in second-half injury time) of the match, which France won 3–1.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.fifa.com/u20worldcup/matches/round=255641/match=300145855/index.html | publisher=[[FIFA|Fédération Internationale de Football Association]] | title = France 3–1 South Korea |date = 2 August 2011 | accessdate = 2 August 2011 }}</ref> He scored one goal in France's final Group A match, 2–0 win over [[Mali national under-20 football team|Mali]]. Lacazette scored twice in the quarterfinal win over [[Nigeria national under-20 football team|Nigeria]] and one goal in the third place match against [[Mexico national under-20 football team|Mexico]]. He finished as the tournament's joint top scorer with 5 goals, along with [[Henrique Almeida]] and [[Álvaro Vázquez]].
===Senior=== On 23 May 2013, Lacazette received his first call-up to the [[France national football team|senior squad]] following the withdrawal of [[Jérémy Ménez]] through injury.<ref name="ESPN FC"/> He made his international debut on 5 June, as a 58th-minute substitute for [[Olivier Giroud]] in a 0–1 friendly defeat against [[Uruguay national football team|Uruguay]] at the [[Estadio Centenario]] in [[Montevideo]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Bairner|first1=Robin|title=Uruguay 1–0 France: Suarez returns to sink les Bleus|url=http://www.goal.com/en-gb/match/uruguay-vs-france/1459132/report?ICID=MP_MS_5|accessdate=31 March 2015|work=Goal.com|date=5 June 2013}}</ref> Lacazette scored his first international goal on 29 March 2015, opening a 2–0 friendly win over [[Denmark national football team|Denmark]] at the [[Stade Geoffroy-Guichard]] in [[Saint-Étienne]]. During the match, he was booed by some of the local supporters due to [[Derby du Rhône|their rivalry with Lyon]].<ref>{{cite news|title=France 2–0 Denmark: Olivier Giroud strikes as Les Bleus bounce back from Brazil loss|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-3017168/France-2-0-Denmark-Olivier-Giroud-strikes-Les-Bleus-bounce-Brazil-loss.html|accessdate=31 March 2015|work=Daily Mail|publisher=Associated Press|date=29 March 2015}}</ref> On 14 November 2017, Lacazette netted a brace for France during a friendly away to Germany in an eventual 2–2 draw.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eurosport.com/football/international-friendlies/2017/live-germany-france_mtc998614/live.shtml|title=Germany 2–2 France|website=Eurosport.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/41884902|title=Germany 2–2 France|website=BBC.com}}</ref>
On 17 May 2018, he was named on the standby list for the 23 man [[French national football team|French squad]] for the [[2018 World Cup]] in [[Russia]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/sport/soccer/english-soccer/anthony-martial-left-out-of-23-man-france-world-cup-squad-1.3499529|title=Anthony Martial left out of 23-man France World Cup squad|work=The Irish Times|access-date=2018-06-04|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.skysports.com/amp/football/news/12025/11376691/alexandre-lacazette-and-anthony-martial-on-standby-for-france-world-cup-squad-and-dimitri-payet-out|title=Alexandre Lacazette and Anthony Martial on standby for France World Cup squad and Dimitri Payet out|publisher=Sky Sports|website=www.skysports.com}}</ref>
==Style of play== Lacazette previously played as a [[Midfielder#Winger|winger]] for Lyon, before becoming a [[Striker (association football)|striker]].<ref name="Sky_14Jul2015">{{cite web|last1=Laurence|first1=Martin|title=Lyon's Alexandre Lacazette could be solution to Arsenal's striker dilemma|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11670/9912559/lyons-alexandre-lacazette-could-be-solution-to-arsenals-striker-dilemma|website=Sky Sports|accessdate=3 July 2017|language=en}}</ref> As well as goalscoring and finishing ability, characteristics of his game are pace, strength, balance, technique, [[Dribbling#Association football|dribbling]], link-up play, and ability with either foot. He is also a hard-working player, who presses the opposition and wins the ball back using his defensive skills and tackling ability.<ref name="FFT_22Aug2014">{{cite web|last1=LeGrand|first1=Dylan|title=Everything you need to know about... Alexandre Lacazette|url=https://www.fourfourtwo.com/features/everything-you-need-know-about-alexandre-lacazette|website=FourFourTwo|accessdate=3 July 2017|language=en|date=22 August 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.espn.in/soccer/blog/name/78/post/2213097/headline |title=Alexandre Lacazette: Could the Lyon forward spark Liverpool's firepower? |publisher=ESPN FC |last1=Dorrington |first1=Nick |date=23 December 2014 |accessdate=19 January 2019 }}</ref><ref name="Lacazette Wright">{{cite web |url=http://www.espn.com/soccer/soccer-transfers/story/3153525/alexandre-lacazette-can-be-like-ian-wright-for-arsenal-gerard-houllier |title=Alexandre Lacazette can be 'like Ian Wright' for Arsenal - Gerard Houllier |publisher=ESPN FC |last1=Karen |first1=Mattias |date=5 July 2017 |accessdate=19 January 2019 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/oct/07/fulham-arsenal-premier-league-match-report |title=Alexandre Lacazette keeps up fine form as stylish Arsenal sweep Fulham aside |work=The Guardian |last1=Fifield |first1=Dominic |date=7 October 2018 |accessdate=19 January 2019 }}</ref> Fellow Frenchman [[Gérard Houllier]] said in July 2017 that Lacazette "is a bit like" former Arsenal striker [[Ian Wright]].<ref name="metro.co.uk"/><ref name="Lacazette Wright"/>

Özil 850 0704.jpg | image_size = | caption = Özil with [[German national football team|Germany]] in 2018 | fullname = Mesut Özil<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.premierleague.com/news/612828 |title=Updated squads for 2017/18 Premier League confirmed |publisher=Premier League |date=2 February 2018 |accessdate=10 February 2018}}</ref> | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1988|10|15|df=y}}<ref>{{cite web |title=FIFA World Cup South Africa 2010: List of players: Germany |url=https://www.fifa.com/mm/document/tournament/competition/01/22/85/78/fwc_2010_squadlists.pdf |publisher=FIFA |format=PDF |page=11 |date=4 June 2010 |accessdate=10 February 2018}}</ref> | birth_place = [[Gelsenkirchen]], West Germany | height = 1.83 m<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.dfb.de/datencenter/personen/mesut-oezil/spieler|title=Mesut Özil - Spielerprofil|website=DFB Datencenter|accessdate=31 January 2019}}</ref> | position = [[Midfielder#Attacking midfielder|Attacking midfielder]] | currentclub = [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] | clubnumber = 10 | youthyears1 = 1995–1998 | youthclubs1 = Westfalia 04 Gelsenkirchen | youthyears2 = 1998–1999 | youthclubs2 = Teutonia Schalke-Nord | youthyears3 = 1999–2000 | youthclubs3 = Falke Gelsenkirchen | youthyears4 = 2000–2005 | youthclubs4 = [[Rot-Weiss Essen]] | youthyears5 = 2005–2006 | youthclubs5 = [[FC Schalke 04|Schalke 04]] | years1 = 2006–2008 | clubs1 = [[FC Schalke 04|Schalke 04]] | caps1 = 30 | goals1 = 0 | years2 = 2008–2010 | clubs2 = [[SV Werder Bremen|Werder Bremen]] | caps2 = 71 | goals2 = 13 | years3 = 2010–2013 | clubs3 = [[Real Madrid C.F.|Real Madrid]] | caps3 = 105 | goals3 = 19 | years4 = 2013– | clubs4 = [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] | caps4 = 158 | goals4 = 31 | nationalyears1 = 2006–2007 | nationalteam1 = [[Germany national youth football team|Germany U19]] | nationalcaps1 = 11 | nationalgoals1 = 4 | nationalyears2 = 2007–2009 | nationalteam2 = [[Germany national under-21 football team|Germany U21]] | nationalcaps2 = 16 | nationalgoals2 = 5 | nationalyears3 = 2009–2018 | nationalteam3 = [[Germany national football team|Germany]] | nationalcaps3 = 92 | nationalgoals3 = 23 | club-update = 10:18, 28 February 2019 (UTC) | nationalteam-update = 16:19, 27 June 2018 (UTC) | medaltemplates = {{MedalCountry|{{fb|GER}}}} {{MedalCompetition|[[FIFA World Cup]]}} {{Medal|W|[[2014 FIFA World Cup|2014]]|}} {{Medal|3rd|[[2010 FIFA World Cup|2010]]|}} {{MedalCompetition|[[UEFA European Championship]]}} {{Medal|B|[[UEFA Euro 2012|2012]]|}}<!-- Though there was no third place playoff, UEFA decided in the 2012 edition to award the semi-final losers (Germany and Portugal) bronze medals for the first time: https://www.uefa.com/MultimediaFiles/Download/competitions/euro/91/87/57/918757_download.pdf --> {{MedalCompetition|[[UEFA European Under-21 Championship]]}} {{Medal|W|[[2009 UEFA European Under-21 Championship|2009]]|}} }} '''Mesut Özil''' ({{IPA-de|ˈmeːzut ˈøːzil}}, {{IPA-tr|meˈsut ˈœzil|lang}}; born 15 October 1988) is a German professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays for {{English football updater|Arsenal}} club [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]]. He is considered to be one of the best players in the world.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2016/11/02/ranking-the-20-best-players-in-the-premier-league-october-2016/mesut-ozil/ | title=Ranking the best players in the Premier League | work=The Daily Telegraph | date=2 November 2016 | accessdate=11 August 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2017/10/13/mesut-ozil-still-one-best-players-world-says-arsene-wenger/ | title=Özil still 'one of the world's best' says Wenger | work=The Daily Telegraph | date=13 October 2017 | accessdate=11 August 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.goal.com/en-gb/news/ozil-is-one-of-the-best-players-in-the-world-under-fire/1l89o8e6gg6dn1bfaik226ji20 | title=Özil still 'one of the world's best' says Reus | publisher=Goal | date=25 June 2018 | accessdate=11 August 2018}}</ref>
Özil plays mostly as an attacking midfielder, but can also be deployed as a winger. He began his senior career as a member of his hometown club [[FC Schalke 04|Schalke 04]] in the [[Bundesliga]], departing two seasons later to join [[SV Werder Bremen|Werder Bremen]] for €5 million. He garnered break-out attention at the [[2010 FIFA World Cup]], where at age 22, Özil was instrumental in the side's campaign where they reached the semi-finals, losing to eventual champions [[Spain national football team|Spain]]. He was also nominated for the [[Golden Ball (FIFA)|Golden Ball Award]], as well as being ranked first in assists in major European and domestic competitions, with 25.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.imscouting.com/global-news-article/The-top-10-assists-leaders-in-Europe-for-201011/13447/ | title=The top 10 assists leaders in Europe for 2010⁄11 | publisher=imscouting.com | date=30 May 2011 | accessdate=13 May 2012}}</ref> This garnered him a €15 million transfer to [[La Liga]] club [[Real Madrid]].
At Madrid, Özil won the [[Copa del Rey]] in his first season, before registering a league high 17 assists as the Spanish side won the league title in the [[2011–12 La Liga|following season]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/stats/assists/_/league/ESP.1/year/2010/spanish-primera-division?cc=5901 | title=Spanish La Liga | publisher=EXPN Soccernat | accessdate=13 May 2012}}</ref> He also won the [[Supercopa de España]] in the same season, becoming renowned for his technical skills and creativity; due to his agility, finesse and versatility as an [[Midfielder#Attacking midfielder|attacking midfielder]], he has also been compared to [[Zinedine Zidane]] by former manager [[José Mourinho]].<ref name=ESPN>{{cite web|url=http://www.espnstar.com/football/primera-liga/news/detail/item807157/Mourinho:-Ozil-will-make-history-at-Real/|title=Mourinho: Ozil will make history at Real|publisher=ESPNSTAR.com|date=26 May 2012|accessdate=26 May 2012}}</ref>
Following a second-place La Liga finish to rivals [[FC Barcelona|Barcelona]] in the [[2012-13 La Liga|2012–13]] season, Özil relocated to England to join [[Premier League]] side [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] in a then club-record deal worth £42.5 million (€50 million),<ref name="Arsenal-sign-1">{{cite news|url=http://www.arsenal.com/news/news-archive/german-international-ozil-joins-arsenal|title=German international Özil joins Arsenal|date=2 September 2013|accessdate=2 September 2013|publisher=Arsenal F.C.}}</ref> making him the [[List of most expensive association football transfers|most expensive German player of all time]].<ref name="Arsenal-sign-2">{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/23929339 |title=Mesut Özil: Arsenal sign Real Madrid midfielder for £42.4m |publisher=BBC |date=2 September 2013 | accessdate = 4 September 2013 | first = David | last = Ornstein}}</ref><ref name="Arsenal-sign-3">{{cite news |url=http://www.espn.co.uk/football/sport/story/234697.html |title= Arsenal smash club record to sign Mesut Özil |date=2 September 2013 |work=The Guardian | accessdate = 4 September 2013}}</ref> During his first season, Özil helped end the club's largely publicised [[History of Arsenal F.C. (1966–present)|nine-year trophy drought]], winning the [[2014 FA Cup Final|FA Cup]] in 2014. He later became victorious in two more FA Cup campaigns, while also winning the [[FA Community Shield]]. Özil would also record the second most assists (19) in a Premier League season in [[2014–15 Premier League|2014–15]], as well as being named in multiple teams of the season in England.
At international level, Özil played 92 matches for the Germany national team, scoring 23 goals, and registered 40 assists. He has also won a record five German Player of the Year awards. Özil represented his country in three [[FIFA World Cup]]s, as well as two [[UEFA European Championship]]s, and was an integral part in both the 2010 FIFA World Cup and [[UEFA Euro 2012]] team in South Africa and Ukraine, starring as the joint-highest assist provider in both competitions. Özil was also a key contributor as Germany won the [[2014 FIFA World Cup]] in Brazil, gaining several plaudits for his versatility and creativity. After the [[2018 FIFA World Cup]], Özil [[Mesut Özil#Retirement controversy|retired from international competition]], alleging discrimination and disrespect by the [[German Football Association]] (DFB) and the German media.
==Club career== ===Schalke 04=== After plying his trade at youth level for various clubs in [[Gelsenkirchen]], including a five-year stint for [[Rot-Weiss Essen]], Özil moved to the youth system of [[FC Schalke 04|Schalke 04]] in 2005. He was deployed a midfielder and wore 17 as his squad number, after starting as a playmaker and central attacking midfielder in the place of the suspended [[Lincoln (footballer)|Lincoln]] in [[Ligapokal]] matches against [[Bayer 04 Leverkusen|Bayer Leverkusen]] and [[FC Bayern Munich|Bayern Munich]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kicker.de/fussball/bundesliga/startseite/artikel/352932|title=Ein 17-Jähriger soll Lincoln ersetzen|publisher=kicker.de|language=German|accessdate=13 November 2007|date=27 July 2006|author=Jean-Julien Beer}}</ref> Upon making the first team at Schalke, he was described as "the next big thing". However, soon after declining an offer from Schalke 04, claiming that a yearly salary of €1.5 million would not be enough, he eventually fell out with club management and moved on to [[SV Werder Bremen|Werder Bremen]] in January 2008.<ref name="Mesut Özil Bio">{{cite web|url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/player/_/id/84775/mesut-ozil?cc=5901|title=Mesut Özil Bio|publisher=espnsoccernet.com|accessdate=9 November 2010}}</ref> This led to [[Mirko Slomka]], the then-Schalke 04 manager, claiming that Özil would not play another match for Schalke 04.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.spiegel.de/sport/fussball/kurzpaesse-ewerthon-nach-barcelona-kuffour-nach-amsterdam-a-531698.html | title=Kurzpässe: Ewerthon nach Barcelona, Kuffour nach Amsterdam | work=Der Spiegel | date=29 January 2008}}</ref>
===Werder Bremen=== [[File:Mesut Özil Werder Bremen.jpg|thumb|upright|Özil with [[SV Werder Bremen|Werder Bremen]] in April 2010]] On 31 January 2008, Özil moved to [[SV Werder Bremen|Werder Bremen]] for a reported fee of {{€|5 million}}, signing a contract with the German club until 30 June 2011. Other than Werder Bremen, [[Hannover 96]] and [[VfB Stuttgart]] were reportedly interested as well in binding Özil to their respective clubs, however did not want to pay such a high transfer fee.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.spiegel.de/sport/fussball/millionen-deal-bremen-verpflichtet-schalker-oezil-a-532301.html | title= Millionen-Deal: Bremen verpflichtet Schalker Özil | work= Der Spiegel | date=31 January 2008}}</ref> After transferring to Werder Bremen, Özil got the jersey number 11. On 26 April 2008 (30th match day) Özil scored the go-ahead goal in the 33rd minute against [[Karlsruher SC]], to put his team up 2–1. This was Özil's very first Bundesliga goal. He played in twelve games throughout the second half of the season, six times playing in the starting formation, becoming second with Werder Bremen in the Bundesliga at the end of the 2007–08 season.
Although Bremen failed to get going in their 2008–09 Bundesliga season, eventually finishing a disappointing tenth, Özil managed to make a significant impact in most games and came away with a respectable three goals and 15 assists that highlighted his attacking credentials.<ref name="Shapland, Dave"/> He helped lead the North German club to the [[2009 DFB-Pokal Final|2009 DFB-Pokal]] with the winning goal in a 1–0 victory over [[Bayer 04 Leverkusen|Bayer Leverkusen]] in Berlin.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.4to40.com/wordpress/biographies-for-kids/mesut-oezil/|title=Mesut Oezil|publisher=4to40.com|accessdate=29 October 2015}}</ref> He also excelled in Europe where he led Werder Bremen to the final of the last ever [[UEFA Cup]], losing out to [[FC Shakhtar Donetsk|Shakhtar Donetsk]] of Ukraine.<ref name="Shapland, Dave">{{cite web|url=http://www.adifferentleague.co.uk/p6_47_787_bundesliga-player-profile-mesut-ozil-werder-bremen.html|title=Bundesliga player profile – Mesut Ozil, Werder Bremen|last=Shapland|first=Dave|publisher=adifferentleague.co.uk|date=28 November 2009|accessdate=9 November 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101119215410/http://www.adifferentleague.co.uk/p6_47_787_bundesliga-player-profile-mesut-ozil-werder-bremen.html|archivedate=19 November 2010}}</ref>
In the 2009–10 season, Özil became the key playmaker of Werder Bremen, stepping into the shoes of Brazilian [[Diego (footballer, born 1985)|Diego]] who had left for [[Juventus F.C.|Juventus]], was named the best player of the first leg of the 2009 Bundesliga season.<ref name="Real profile English">{{cite web|url=http://www.realmadrid.com/cs/Satellite/en/1193041476158/1330012508587/jugador/Jugador/Ozil.htm|title=Mesut Özil|publisher=Real Madrid C.F|accessdate=27 April 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120428162816/http://www.realmadrid.com/cs/Satellite/en/1193041476158/1330012508587/jugador/Jugador/Ozil.htm|archivedate=28 April 2012}}</ref> On 1 May 2010, the 33rd match day, Özil played his 100th Bundesliga game, scoring the 1–0 lead in a 2–0 win against his former club Schalke 04. Özil went on and led Werder Bremen to become third in the league and again to the DFB-Pokal final, however this time it was lost against Bayern Munich by 0–4. In his [[2009–10 Bundesliga|second season]], Bremen finished a respectable third, with Özil contributing 9 goals and 17 assists in 31 league fixture appearances. During the 2009–10 season, Özil was also declared as the "best player of the first half of the season".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sportschau.de/sp/kurzmeldungen.jsp?meldung=7&popup | title=Sportschau.de: Wahl – Mesut Özil ist Spieler der Hinrunde | publisher=Sportschau | language = German |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090928021958/http://www.sportschau.de/sp/kurzmeldungen.jsp?meldung=7&popup |archivedate=28 September 2009}}</ref>
===Real Madrid=== ====2010–11 season==== [[File:Mesut ozil v drese realu madrid.jpg|thumb|upright|left|Özil playing for [[Real Madrid CF|Real Madrid]] in 2010]] Due to his performances in the [[2010 FIFA World Cup]], Özil ensured his place among Europe's top young talents. He was sought by teams like [[FC Barcelona|Barcelona]], [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] and [[Real Madrid C.F.|Real Madrid]]. English striker [[Wayne Rooney]] was one of the many admirers Özil had garnered with his performances in the World Cup, and had even asked [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] manager [[Alex Ferguson|Sir Alex Ferguson]] to sign the German playmaker.<ref>{{cite news | url = https://www.theguardian.com/football/2013/oct/22/ferguson-wayne-rooney-sign-mesut-ozil-book | title = Sir Alex Ferguson: 'Wayne Rooney wanted me to sign Mesut Özil' | work = The Guardian | date = 22 October 2013 | accessdate = 29 March 2014 | first = Owen | last = Gibson}}</ref> There were reports claiming that a deal was struck for a transfer to Barcelona, but Werder Bremen denied the reports and on 17 August 2010, the team announced that they had reached an agreement with Real Madrid for Özil's transfer.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.realmadrid.com/cs/Satellite/en/1330010084519/noticia/Noticia/Mesut_Ozil_to_play_for_Real_Madrid.htm|title=Mesut Özil to Play for Real Madrid|accessdate=17 August 2010|publisher=Real Madrid C.F.|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100819014107/http://www.realmadrid.com/cs/Satellite/en/1330010084519/noticia/Noticia/Mesut_Ozil_to_play_for_Real_Madrid.htm|archivedate=19 August 2010}}</ref> The transfer fee is believed to have been in the region of €15 million.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/europe/8921836.stm|title=Real Madrid confirm signing of Germany star Mesut Ozil|publisher=BBC sport|date=17 August 2010|accessdate=17 August 2010}}</ref> Upon signing, Özil said, "When the offer came in to join Real Madrid, there is no decision to make. Let's be honest – you don't refuse this club. I was in no rush to leave Werder Bremen, but this is one club you say yes to. They are an institution, a club with a fantastic history, stadium and squad full of world-class players. The prospect of performing at the Bernabéu is so awesome you jump straight in."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/columns/story?id=821820&sec=uefachampionsleague&root=uefachampionsleague&cc=5901|title=Mesut Ozil Interview: Real Madrid's new star|date=10 September 2010|accessdate=22 April 2012|publisher=ESPN FC}}</ref> Özil made his debut on 22 August in a friendly match against [[Hércules CF|Hércules]], which Real Madrid won 3–1.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.goal.com/en/news/12/spain/2010/08/22/2082959/hercules-1-3-real-madrid-benzema-brace-seals-friendly|title=Hercules 1–3 Real Madrid: Benzema Brace Seals Friendly Triumph|publisher=Goal.com|date=22 August 2010| accessdate=23 August 2010|last=Madden|first=Paul}}</ref> His jersey numbers were changed often before the season started. He was given the number 26 in the pre-season and 19 for his debut. But following the transfer of [[Rafael van der Vaart]] to [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]], he was given the vacant 23.
Özil was brought in to back up teammate [[Kaká]], but due to his surgery, Özil obtained a starting role. He then made his La Liga debut for Real Madrid as a substitute for [[Ángel Di María]] in the 62nd minute against [[RCD Mallorca|Mallorca]], which Real Madrid drew 0–0.<ref name="Real Madrid">{{cite web|url=http://www.realmadrid.com/cs/Satellite/en/1330012984541/noticia/Cronica/1330012984541.htm |title=Report: The Whites make their debut in the 2010/11 edition of La Liga |accessdate=16 September 2010 |publisher=Real Madrid C.F. |date=29 August 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100902025048/http://www.realmadrid.com/cs/Satellite/en/1330012984541/noticia/Cronica/1330012984541.htm |archivedate=2 September 2010 |df= }}</ref> [[File:Mesut Özil and Daniele Bonera.jpg|thumb|right|Özil taking on [[Daniele Bonera]] of [[A.C. Milan|Milan]] during the [[2010–11 UEFA Champions League]]]] He made his season debut in the [[UEFA Champions League|Champions League]] on 15 September. He got his first assist with Real Madrid in the 74th minute against [[AFC Ajax|Ajax]] after he crossed for a [[Gonzalo Higuaín]] goal.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.realmadrid.com/cs/Satellite/en/1330015494251/noticia/Cronica/The_Whites_earn_a_victory_in_their_Champions_League_debut.htm|title=Report: The Whites earn a victory in their Champions League debut|accessdate=16 September 2010|publisher=Real Madrid C.F.|date=15 September 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100918221222/http://www.realmadrid.com/cs/Satellite/en/1330015494251/noticia/Cronica/The_Whites_earn_a_victory_in_their_Champions_League_debut.htm|archivedate=18 September 2010}}</ref>
He walked off the pitch as a second-half substitute to standing ovations in his first two games as a starter at the [[Santiago Bernabéu Stadium]]. His first goal came in a league match against [[Deportivo de La Coruña]] on 3 October 2010, in a 6–1 victory.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.goal.com/en/match/47748/real-madrid-vs-deportivo/report|title=Real Madrid 6–1 Deportivo La Coruna: Ronaldo Brace Sees Los Blancos Go Above Barcelona|publisher=goal.com|date=3 October 2010|accessdate=20 October 2010|first=Subhankar|last=Mondal}}</ref> Özil's first Champions League goal with Real came in the 14th minute against [[A.C. Milan|Milan]] on 19 October 2010.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2010/oct/19/real-madrid-milan-live|title=Real Madrid v Milan – as it happened|work=The Guardian|date=19 October 2010|accessdate=20 October 2010|first=Tom|last=Lutz}}</ref> On 22 December, he made his debut in the [[Copa del Rey]], scoring once in an 8–0 victory over [[UD Levante|Levante]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.goal.com/en/match/54213/real-madrid-vs-levante/report|title=Real Madrid vs Levante Report | publisher=Goal.com|date=23 December 2010|accessdate=23 December 2010}}</ref>
He finished [[2010–11 Real Madrid C.F. season|the season]] with 25 assists, the highest for any player in any major European competition that season. Özil's performances for Real Madrid during his first season were praised by media, fans and players.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.realmadrid.com/cs/Satellite/en/1330015068338/noticia/Noticia/Praise_for_Mesut_Ozil.htm |title=Praise for Mesut Ozil |date=13 September 2010 |accessdate=4 October 2010 |publisher=Real Madrid C.F. |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101006104442/http://www.realmadrid.com/cs/Satellite/en/1330015068338/noticia/Noticia/Praise_for_Mesut_Ozil.htm |archivedate=6 October 2010 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.realmadrid.com/cs/Satellite/en/1330046715358/noticia/Noticia/Ozil_s_magic_amazes_the_entire_planet.htm|title=Ozil's magic amazes the entire planet|publisher=Real Madrid C.F.|date=7 March 2011|accessdate=7 March 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110310153157/http://www.realmadrid.com/cs/Satellite/en/1330046715358/noticia/Noticia/Ozil_s_magic_amazes_the_entire_planet.htm|archivedate=10 March 2011}}</ref>
====2011–12 season==== Özil began wearing the number 10 shirt for Real Madrid in [[2011–12 La Liga|2011–12]], signalling manager [[José Mourinho]]'s intent to use the German international as his main playmaker.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.goal.com/en-india/news/2175/la-liga/2011/07/23/2587139/mesut-ozil-to-wear-no10-shirt-for-real-madrid-in-2011-12|title=Mesut Ozil To Wear No.10 Shirt For Real Madrid in 2011–12|publisher=Goal.com| date=23 July 2011|accessdate=31 July 2011}}</ref> On 14 August 2011, Özil scored his first goal against Barcelona in ''[[El Clásico]]'' in the first leg of the [[2011 Supercopa de España]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.goal.com/en/match/65089/real-madrid-vs-barcelona/report|title=Real Madrid 2–2 Barcelona: All-square in thrilling Supercopa contest | date=14 August 2011|work=''Goal.com''|accessdate=28 November 2011}}</ref> On 17 August 2011, he was [[sent off]] in the last minute of the second leg of the 2011 Supercopa after an altercation with Barça forward [[David Villa]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.goal.com/en/match/65090/barcelona-vs-real-madrid/report|title=Barcelona 3–2 Real Madrid (Agg. 5–4): Lionel Messi brace wins Supercopa amid violent scenes at Camp Nou|date=17 August 2011|work=''Goal.com''|accessdate=28 August 2011}}</ref> Özil expressed his desire to end his football days at the club in an interview with German magazine ''kicker'', saying, "I'd like to end my career at Real Madrid. I know it will be difficult because I have many more years ahead of me and many younger and good players will also be out there, but I want to be part of that future. I know what I'm capable of, and I'm convinced, I'll stay at Real Madrid many years."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.realmadrid.com/cs/Satellite/en/1330080343016/noticia/Noticia/Ozil:__I_d_like_to_end_my_career_at_Real_Madrid_.htm|title=Ozil: "I'd like to end my career at Real Madrid"|publisher=Real Madrid C.F.|date=2 February 2012|accessdate=2 February 2012}}</ref>
Özil was on the short-list of the [[FIFA Ballon d'Or]] award.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.fifa.com/ballondor/media/newsid=1535258/index.html |title=Men's shortlists for FIFA Ballon d'Or Gala 2011 revealed |date=1 November 2011 |publisher=FIFA |accessdate=1 July 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111221040029/http://www.fifa.com/ballondor/media/newsid%3D1535258/index.html |archivedate=21 December 2011 |df= }}</ref> [[File:Mesut Oezil Boots Santiago Bernabeu.jpg|thumb|Özil's boots on display at the Santiago Bernabéu museum]]
He finished atop the [[2011–12 La Liga|La Liga]] assists chart, with 17 assists. On 2 May 2012, he helped Real Madrid to clinch a record 32nd [[La Liga]] title as he assisted Real's first goal and scored the second goal against Bilbao, which Real Madrid later won by 3–0. Eleven days later, Özil scored two goals in the final game of the regular season against Mallorca, once again consolidating his excellent performance with the club. The win made Real the first club in the Spanish top flight to ever reach 100 points in a single season.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/report/_/id/323691?cc=5901|title=Ton-up Real set new landmark|publisher=ESPN Soccernet|date=13 May 2012|accessdate=13 May 2012}}</ref> His fine form with Real Madrid and German national team saw him earn nomination for [[UEFA Best Player in Europe Award]], in which he finished tenth, being the youngest player to feature in the Top 10.<ref>{{cite web|title=Iniesta, Messi, Ronaldo up for Best Player Award|url=http://www.uefa.com/memberassociations/news/newsid=1842518.html|publisher=UEFA|accessdate=8 June 2017|date=14 August 2012}}</ref>
====2012–13 season==== With arrival of [[Luka Modrić]] before the start of the season, some in the media claimed Özil was unhappy at Real Madrid, but he later rejected such talk and claimed he was happy at the club and looking forward to competing for his place.<ref>{{cite news |title= Mesut Ozil reiterates happiness |url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/news/story/_/id/1186783/mesut-ozil-happy-with-competition-at-real-madrid |publisher= ESPN | date = 11 October 2012 | accessdate = 12 October 2012}}</ref> After the start of the season, he added the [[Supercopa de España]] title to his honours. In league play, he provided an important assist to [[Cristiano Ronaldo]] who equalised in a 2–2 draw against Barcelona at Camp Nou.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://espnfc.com/uk/en/report/348447/report.html?soccernet=true&cc=5739 | title = Ronaldo, Messi share spoils in draw | publisher = ESPN FC | date = 7 October 2012 | accessdate = 16 October 2012}}</ref> On 6 November, Özil scored a crucial 89th-minute free-kick to rescue a draw for Real Madrid and secure a point against [[Borussia Dortmund]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Mesut Ozil saves Real Madrid with late goal against Borussia Dortmund |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2012/nov/06/real-madrid-borussia-dortmund-champions-league |newspaper= The Guardian |location=London |date= 6 November 2012 |accessdate= 9 November 2012 |first = Sid | last = Lowe}}</ref> He continued his fine form in the league as he scored another brace against Real Valladolid to rescue Real Madrid in a 3–2 win.<ref>{{cite news |title=Ozil to the rescue after Real hit by brace from former Man United flop Manucho |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-2245233/Mesut-Ozil-rescue-Real-Madrid-hit-brace-Man-United-flop-Manucho.html |date=8 December 2012 |accessdate=14 December 2012 |newspaper=Daily Mail |location=London}}</ref> He then went on to finish the season with 29 assists, although Real Madrid did not win any silverware except for the Supercopa de España, Özil's performance was praised. At the end of the season, Özil had 26 assists, more than any other player in the leagues.
===Arsenal=== [[File:Mesut Özil Arsenal (4).jpg|thumbnail|Özil taking a free kick for [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] against [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke City]] on 22 September 2013]] On 2 September 2013, Özil agreed to join English side [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]].<ref name="Arsenal-sign-1" /> Both the fee paid for Özil as well as the contract duration were undisclosed, but they are believed to be around £42.5 million (€50 million) for a five-year deal.<ref name="Arsenal-sign-2" /> The transfer makes him the [[List of most expensive association football transfers|most expensive German football player of all time]].<ref name="Arsenal-sign-3" /> Özil was assigned the number 11 shirt and the centre-attacking midfield role by the team.<ref name="Arsenal-sign-4">{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-2409704/Mesut-Ozil-signs-Arsenal-did-Real-Madrid-bully-Germany-star-42-5million-tramsfer.html|title=Did Real Madrid 'bully' Ozil into joining Arsenal? Claims in Germany suggest £42.5m record signing was forced into move|date=3 September 2013|accessdate=3 September 2013|work=Daily Mail | first = Laurie | last = Whitwell }}</ref> Contract leaks in January 2016, however, have revealed that the record fee was actually broken down to £37.4 million (€44 million) with a further £5.1 million (€6 million) split evenly over six years from July 2014, subject to Champions League qualification. A buy-back option also allows Real Madrid a 48-hour first option on Özil should Arsenal agree a sale for the playmaker to another Spanish club.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/arsenal/12119391/Mesut-Ozil-leaked-contract-reveals-Real-Madrid-have-buy-back-option-from-Arsenal.html|title=Mesut Ozil leaked contract reveals Real Madrid have buy-back option from Arsenal |author=Jeremy Wilson |work=The Daily Telegraph |date=25 January 2016 |accessdate=26 January 2016 }}</ref>
Özil said of the transfer, "At the weekend, I was certain I would stay at Real Madrid but afterwards I realised I did not have the faith from the coach or the bosses. I am a player who needs this faith and that is what I have felt from Arsenal, which is why I have joined."<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.standard.co.uk/sport/football/with-arsene-wengers-belief-i-can-get-even-better--mesut-ozil-8796397.html |title='With Arsene Wenger's belief I can get even better' – Mesut Ozil |date=3 September 2013 |accessdate=3 September 2013 |newspaper=London Evening Standard | first = James | last = Olley}}</ref> In Özil's first press conference, he said: "I would have come here for free, that wouldn't have been a problem." Özil additionally stated that [[Arsène Wenger]] played an important role in his decision: "When I spoke to Arsène Wenger on the phone, he was full of respect, and as a player, I need that."<ref name="Arsenal profile">{{cite web | url = http://www.arsenal.com/first-team/players/mesut-ozil | title = Mesut Ozil | publisher = Arsenal F.C. | accessdate = 9 March 2014}}</ref> Several Real Madrid players were dissatisfied with Özil leaving the club, including Cristiano Ronaldo, who said, "He was the player who best knew my moves in front of goal ... I'm angry about Özil leaving."<ref name="Ozil Daily Mail">{{cite news | first =Laurie | last = Whitwell |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-2410973/Cristiano-Ronaldo-angry-Mesut-Ozil-transfer-Real-Madrid-Arsenal.html?ico=sport%5Eheadlines |title=Cristiano Ronaldo angry at Mesut Ozil transfer from Real Madrid to Arsenal |newspaper=Daily Mail |location=London |date=4 September 2013 |accessdate=4 September 2013}}</ref>
====2013–14 season==== [[File:Mesut Özil (9881761465) Cropped.jpg|thumb|right|upright=.8|Özil playing for Arsenal in 2013]] Özil made his debut for Arsenal in their league game away to [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] on 14 September 2013. He assisted [[Olivier Giroud]]'s goal in the 11th minute of the match as they went on to win 3–1.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/23999428 |title=Sunderland 1–3 Arsenal |publisher=BBC Sport |date=14 September 2013 |accessdate=14 September 2013}}</ref> Three days after that, he made his [[2013–14 UEFA Champions League|Champions League]] debut for Arsenal against [[Olympique de Marseille|Marseille]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/24044269 |title=Marseille 1–2 Arsenal |publisher=BBC Sport |date=18 September 2013 |accessdate=27 September 2013 |last=Magowan |first=Alistair}}</ref> Just over three weeks after making his debut for Arsenal, he made his [[Emirates Stadium|home]] debut against [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke City]] in a 3–1 victory. He was involved in all three goals, with two assists and a free kick which was saved but fell into [[Aaron Ramsey]]'s path.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/24098512 |title=Arsenal 3–1 Stoke City |publisher=BBC Sport |date=22 September 2013 |accessdate=27 September 2013 |last=Magowan |first=Alistair}}</ref> He scored his first goal for Arsenal, a brilliantly controlled finish from a Ramsey cross, in a 2–0 win against [[S.S.C. Napoli|Napoli]] in the Champions League.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.arsenal.com/match/report/1314/post/first-team/arsenal-v-napoli-story-so-far |title=Arsenal 2–0 Napoli – Match Report |publisher=Arsenal F.C. |date=1 October 2013 |accessdate=2 October 2013}}</ref> On 19 October, he scored his first two [[2013–14 Premier League|Premier League]] goals during the 4–1 home win against [[Norwich City F.C.|Norwich City]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2013/oct/19/arsenal-norwich-city-premier-league|title=Arsenal and Mesut Özil turn on style to sweep past Norwich City |date=20 October 2013 |work=The Guardian |location=London}}</ref> Özil played in all six of Arsenal's games in November. The German playmaker provided the cross for [[Jack Wilshere]]'s second goal against Marseille and gave further assists for Aaron Ramsey and [[Mathieu Flamini]] in the 3–0 win over [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]]. Özil missed the chance to score his fourth Arsenal goal when he saw his penalty in the win over Marseille saved by [[Steve Mandanda]].<ref name="Arsenal profile" />
In October, Özil was again short-listed for the FIFA Ballon d'Or award, along with former teammate Cristiano Ronaldo.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.fifa.com/ballondor/news/newsid=2207371/ | title = Men's shortlists for FIFA Ballon d'Or 2013 revealed | publisher = FIFA | date = 29 October 2013 | accessdate = 29 March 2014}}</ref> Özil was also featured on the [[UEFA Team of the Year]]. Özil began December with two goals in as many games against [[Hull City A.F.C.|Hull City]] and [[Everton F.C.|Everton]]. A minor shoulder injury forced him out of the final game of December in a win against [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]]. After the 6–3 defeat at [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] in which he made another assist, Özil was involved in an altercation with teammate [[Per Mertesacker]], who was angry with Özil's failure to thank the travelling supporters, an omission for which he subsequently apologised via Facebook.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.espn.co.uk/football/sport/story/266435.html |title=Ozil apologises to Arsenal fans |publisher=ESPN |date=14 December 2013 |accessdate=1 September 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last=Bevan |first=Chris |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/25383956 |title=Arsenal boss Arsene Wenger plays down importance of Man City loss |publisher=BBC Sport |date=14 December 2013 |accessdate=5 February 2014}}</ref> [[File:Olivier Giroud x Mesut Özil v Southampton - 23 Nov 2013 (cropped).jpg|thumb|left|Özil and [[Olivier Giroud]] before kick-off against [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] on 23 November 2013]]
Özil started four of Arsenal's six games in January. The playmaker missed Arsenal's victory over Cardiff City on New Year's Day with a shoulder injury before returning to make a late appearance from the bench against Tottenham Hotspur in the [[2013–14 FA Cup|FA Cup]]. The 25-year-old produced a slide-rule pass for [[Lukas Podolski]] to score his first goal against [[Coventry City F.C.|Coventry City]] and provided the ball for [[Santi Cazorla]]'s goal against [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] at the end of the month to take his assist tally to 10.<ref name="Arsenal profile" />
February was a difficult month for Özil, as he struggled to reach the heights he showed in his first few months at the club. The German playmaker pulled off a brilliant piece of skill to win a penalty against Bayern Munich in the [[2013–14 UEFA Champions League knockout phase|Champions League knockout phase]], but his spot-kick was saved by [[Manuel Neuer]]. Speaking before the draw with Manchester United, Arsène Wenger spoke about Özil, saying, "He has done well, he is adapting as well to the Premier League – we have seen it before [that it takes time]. I wouldn't like to put too much pressure on him because he has been a top-class player until now. He didn't have the best of games [at [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]]] (a 5–1 loss, where Özil was the centre of attention due to a bad performance) but that can happen. He works very hard to adapt to the physical level of the Premier League and for me he is an exceptional player."<ref name="Arsenal profile" />
On 8 March, Özil scored his first goal of 2014 in a 4–1 FA Cup quarter-final win over Everton.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2014/mar/08/arsenal-everton-fa-cup-live-mbm|title=Arsenal v Everton: FA Cup – as it happened|date=8 March 2014|work=The Guardian}}</ref> Özil was showing signs of old form and started in Arsenal's second leg Champions League last 16 clash with Bayern Munich.<ref>{{cite web |last=Cryer |first=Andy |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/26505997 |title=Bayern Munich 1–1 Arsenal (agg 3–1) |publisher=BBC Sport |date=11 March 2014 |accessdate=24 March 2014}}</ref> He was substituted at half-time, and the reasoning behind it was that Özil had suffered a hamstring injury and will face a month out, missing key fixtures against [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] and Manchester City.<ref>{{cite web|last=Ornstein |first=David |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/26544491 |title=Mesut Ozil: Arsenal's record buy out for month with hamstring injury |publisher=BBC Sport |date=13 March 2014 |accessdate=24 March 2014}}</ref>
On 20 April, Özil made an instant impact with a lively display against Hull when he returned to the Arsenal team in a 3–0 win.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.arsenal.com/first-team/players/mesut-ozil|title=Özil returns at Hull|date=20 April 2014|accessdate=20 April 2014|publisher=Arsenal F.C.}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2014/apr/20/hull-city-arsenal-premier-league-match-report|title=Lukas Podolski double eases Arsenal past Hull in FA Cup final rehearsal|date=20 April 2014|accessdate=20 April 2014|work=The Guardian}}</ref> He then returned to goalscoring form with Arsenal's second in their 3–0 win over Newcastle United, and then assisted Olivier Giroud's header.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-2615255/Arsenal-3-0-Newcastle-Gunners-strengthen-hold-fourth-place-brushing-aside-woeful-Toon-Emirates.html | title = Arsenal 3–0 Newcastle: Gunners strengthen hold on fourth place after brushing aside woeful Toon at the Emirates | work = Daily Mail | first = Matt | last = Barlow | date = 28 April 2014 | accessdate = 28 April 2014}}</ref> Manager Wenger praised Özil's impact upon his return, saying, "Mesut Özil is very important for the team. He's been missed while he's been injured. We've missed some very important players in an important period of the season. We're really pleased to have people like him back in the team and performing at the top level because that's what we need."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.arsenal.com/first-team/players/mesut-ozil|title=Wenger praises Özil's impact in Arsenal turnaround|date=28 April 2014|accessdate=29 April 2014|publisher=Arsenal F.C.}}</ref>
Özil played all three of Arsenal's remaining fixtures during the last month of his debut season in England. The German playmaker came off at half-time in extra-time of Arsenal's [[2014 FA Cup Final]] victory over Hull at [[Wembley Stadium]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/27354148| title=Arsenal 3–2 Hull|publisher=BBC Sport| accessdate = 18 May 2014 | date = 17 May 2014 | first = Phil | last = McNulty}}</ref> Speaking before the FA Cup final, Per Mertesacker praised his compatriot's impact on the side during his first season in England. "You could see from the start that he is one of the best players in Europe," said Mertesacker. "His contributions and assists are vital for any club so we are happy to have him back."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.arsenal.com/first-team/players/mesut-ozil| title=Praise from Mertesacker after Özil completes maiden Arsenal season|publisher=Arsenal F.C.| accessdate = 31 May 2014 | date = 30 May 2014 | first = Per | last = Mertesacker}}</ref> Özil completed his maiden season at Arsenal with 13 assists and seven goals in all competitions spanning a course of 40 games.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.espnfc.com/player/84775/mesut-ozil?season=2013|title=Mesut Özil complete stats for 2013/14 season|date=28 April 2014|accessdate=29 April 2014|work=''espnfc.com''}}</ref>
====2014–15 season==== [[File:Mesut Özil on the ball 4 (16234232390).jpg|thumbnail|Özil in a league match against Aston Villa in February 2015]] Özil returned to club training in the middle of August after participating in [[Germany national football team|Germany]]'s [[2014 FIFA World Cup]] win in Brazil. On 23 August, Özil made his first appearance of [[2014–15 Arsenal F.C. season|the season]] in a 2–2 draw with [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] at [[Goodison Park]].
