team|Switzerland]] | nationalcaps5 = 70 | nationalgoals5 = 10 | club-update = 20:28, 2 March 2019 (UTC) | nationalteam-update = 18:48, 22 October 2018 (UTC) }} '''Granit Xhaka''' ({{IPA-sq|ɡɾaˈnit ˈdʒaka}}; born 27 September 1992) is a Swiss professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[midfielder]] for {{English football updater|Arsenal}} club [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] and the [[Switzerland national football team|Switzerland national team]].
Xhaka began his career at hometown club [[FC Basel|Basel]], winning the [[Swiss Super League]] in each of his first two seasons. He then moved to [[Bundesliga]] team [[Borussia Mönchengladbach]] in 2012, developing a reputation as a technically gifted player and natural leader alongside criticism for his temperament.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/15118/10219172/granit-xhaka-profile-of-arsenals-first-summer-signing |title=Granit Xhaka: Profile of Arsenal's first summer signing |publisher=Sky Sports |date=26 May 2016}}</ref> He was made captain of Borussia Mönchengladbach in 2015 at the age of 22, leading the team to [[UEFA Champions' League]] qualification for a second successive season.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/2016/may/26/granit-xhaka-arsenal-leader-borussia-monchengladbach |title=Granit Xhaka: a born leader who will finally bring some grit to Arsenal – Marcus Christenson |first=Marcus |last=Christenson |date=26 May 2016 |work=The Guardian}}</ref> He completed a high-profile transfer to Arsenal in May 2016 for a fee in the region of £30 million.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/15118/10291273/granit-xhaka-could-become-arsenals-third-most-expensive-transfer-at-16330m |title=Granit Xhaka becomes Arsenal's third-most expensive transfer at around £30m}}</ref>
Xhaka was part of the [[Switzerland national under-17 football team|Swiss team]] that won the [[2009 FIFA U-17 World Cup]]. He made his senior debut in 2011 and has won over 60 caps, representing the nation at the [[FIFA World Cup]] in [[2014 FIFA World Cup|2014]] and [[2018 FIFA World Cup|2018]], and at [[UEFA Euro 2016]].
==Early life== Xhaka was born in [[Basel]], [[Switzerland]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.borussia.de/english/season/first-team/squad.html |title=Wir sind Borussia. Herzlich willkommen. – Borussia Mönchengladbach |website=Borussia.de |accessdate=24 September 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.albinfo.ch/de/sport/granit-xhaka-zuhause-bin-ich-sowohl-der-schweiz-wie-kosova |title=Granit Dhaka: Zuhause bin ich sowohl in der Schweiz wie in Kosova |quote="Ich bin der Schweiz dankbar für alles. Ich kam in diesem Land auf die Welt"..."Natürlich fühle ich mich zuhause am wohlsten, und das ist in der Schweiz, da ich da geboren und aufgewachsen bin"..."Im Internet in der Wikipedia steht, dass ich in Gjilan geboren sei, doch das ist ein Fehler, von dem ich nicht weiss, wie er entstand." |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140515041005/http://www.albinfo.ch/de/sport/granit-xhaka-zuhause-bin-ich-sowohl-der-schweiz-wie-kosova |archivedate=15 May 2014 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.zdfsport.de/shaqiri-und-xhaka-heiss-auf-die-wm-30462244.html |title=Shaqiri und Xhaka – heiß auf die WM |quote=Den Ruf des frühreifen Fußballers brachte der gebürtige Basler vor knapp eineinhalb Jahren aus der Alpenrepublik mit ins niederrheinische Flachland.}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.fcb.ch/news/show/byItemID/de-de/10044/27991/16/7 |title=Granit Xhaka: "Es ist ein guter Moment für diesen tollen Schritt" |quote=Ich bin in Basel geboren und aufgewachsen|access-date=14 May 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140515004655/http://www.fcb.ch/news/show/byItemID/de-de/10044/27991/16/7|archive-date=15 May 2014|dead-url=yes}}</ref> to [[Albanians|Albanian]] parents, Eli and Ragip Xhaka, originally from [[Kuršumlija]], [[Serbia]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GasLorVV6qE |title=Nga Nishi deri tek Molla e Kuqe |quote=Granit Xhaka und Taulant Xhaka kommen ursprünglich vom Dorf Dzake in Serbie. Dzake befindet sich in der Nähe von Kuršumlija in Serbien. Das wir in dieser Doku ausführlich erwähnt."}}</ref> His father Ragip was a [[political prisoner]]. At the age of 22, as a student at [[University of Pristina (1969–99)|University of Pristina]], Ragip participated in a 1986 student demonstration in Yugoslavia against the central government in Belgrade and, as a result, he was arrested and given a six-year sentence (he spent three and a half years in prison).<ref>{{cite web |last1=Hytner |first1=David |title=Granit Xhaka: ‘My dad’s first few months in jail were OK, then the beatings started’ |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2017/nov/17/granit-xhaka-dad-jail-beatings-arsenal-tottenham-derby |work=The Guardian |accessdate=23 June 2018 |date=17 November 2017}}</ref> Their family moved from [[Podujevo]], [[District of Pristina]] to Switzerland in 1990.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.fcb.ch/sport/show/playerDetailByID/-/30167/72/9/36/de-de/-/25328 |quote=Geburtsort:Basel |title=Taulant Xhaka |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140701182423/http://www.fcb.ch/sport/show/playerDetailByID/-/30167/72/9/36/de-de/-/25328 |archivedate=1 July 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.panorama.com.al/2011/11/16/xhaka-zgjodha-pa-hezitim-zvicren-shqiptaret-me-thone-tradhtar/ |title=Xhaka: Zgjodha pa hezitim Zvicrën, shqiptarët më thonë tradhtar! |quote=Granit, familja juaj vjen nga Kosova, po ju ku keni lindur? Në Zvicër, në Bazel kam lindur. Ashtu si Taulanti, vëllai im. Disa burime informacioni, duke përfshirë këtu edhe "Ëikipedia", kanë njoftuar se kam lindur në Kosovë, por kjo nuk është e vërtetë |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140514225243/http://www.panorama.com.al/2011/11/16/xhaka-zgjodha-pa-hezitim-zvicren-shqiptaret-me-thone-tradhtar/ |archivedate=14 May 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.20min.ch/sport/fussball/story/14450158 |title=Albanien hat schon telefoniert |quote=Bei Granits Mutter beisst der albanische Fussballverband denn auch auf Granit: «Unsere Kinder sind hier geboren worden und zur Schule gegangen. Sie gehören in die Schweiz.»}}</ref>
His older brother, [[Taulant Xhaka]], is also a professional footballer and plays for [[FC Basel]] and the [[Albania national football team|Albania national team]].
==Club career== The brothers started their youth football by [[FC Concordia Basel|Concordia Basel]] and both moved to [[FC Basel|Basel]] in 2002. Xhaka played for various [[FC Basel|Basel]] youth teams and since 2008 has been a member of the U-21 squad. Between 2008 and 2010, he played 37 games for the U-21 team, scoring eleven goals.<ref name="NFT">{{NFT player|id=43459}}</ref>
===Basel=== Former [[FC Basel|Basel]] coach [[Thorsten Fink]] once said. "[[Xherdan Shaqiri]] is the best talent in Switzerland...after Granit Xhaka."<ref name="talent">{{cite web |url=http://www.goal.com/en-gb/news/2914/champions-league/2012/02/22/2921337/better-than-shaqiri-the-teenage-basel-star-who-bayern-munich |title=Better than Shaqiri – the teenage Basel star who Bayern Munich must stop tonight |publisher=Goal.com |accessdate=25 June 2012 |date=22 February 2012}}</ref> Whilst the Swiss National Football Coach, Ottmar Hitzfeld, has dubbed him the 'young [[Schweinsteiger]].'<ref name="talent"/>
Since the beginning of the [[2010–11 Swiss Super League|2010–11]] season, Xhaka played for the Basel first team. He made his first team debut in the third qualifying round of the [[2010–11 UEFA Champions League]] in the away match against [[Debreceni VSC|Debrecen]] in the [[Szusza Ferenc Stadium]]. Towards the end of the match, he scored the second goal in Basel's 2–0 victory. He scored his first Super League goal in the 5–1 home win against [[FC Thun]] on 15 May 2011.<ref name="FC Basel">{{cite web |last=Meister |first=Remo |date=15 May 2011 |url=http://www.fcb.ch/news/show/byItemID/-/10044/25972/26/7/7 |title=Der FCB ist zurück an der Spitze |publisher=FC Basel 1893 |accessdate=15 May 2011 |language=German | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20120405060814/http://www.fcb.ch/news/show/byItemID/-/10044/25972/26/7/7 | archive-date = 5 April 2012 | dead-url = yes }}</ref> At the end of the 2010–11 season, Xhaka won the [[2010–11 Swiss Super League|Super League Championship]] title with Basel and at the end of the 2011–12 season he won the [[Double (association football)|Double]], the [[2011–12 Swiss Super League|League]] Championship title<ref name="sfv 1">{{cite web |url=http://www.fcb.ch/news/show/byItemID/de-de/10044/27863/26/7/7 |title=Der 15. Meistertitel für den FCB – die Bilanz einer grandiosen Saison |publisher=FC Basel 1893 |accessdate=29 April 2012 |date=29 April 2012 |language=German |last=Meister |first=Remo |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131016142727/http://www.fcb.ch/news/show/byItemID/de-de/10044/27863/26/7/7 |archivedate=16 October 2013}}</ref> and the [[2011–12 Swiss Cup|Swiss Cup]]<ref name="sfv 2">{{cite web |year=2012 |url=http://www.football.ch/sfv/chcup/de/telegramm.aspx?tg=1973921 | archive-url = https://archive.is/20121204154542/http://www.football.ch/sfv/chcup/de/telegramm.aspx?tg=1973921 | dead-url = yes | archive-date = 4 December 2012 |title=Matchtelegram FC Basel 1893 5:3 FC Luzern |publisher=football.ch |accessdate=16 May 2012 |language=German}}</ref> with the club.
===Borussia Mönchengladbach=== [[File:Xhaka 1.jpg|thumb|Xhaka with [[Borussia Mönchengladbach]] in 2015]]
On 18 May 2012, Basel announced on their homepage that Xhaka had agreed terms with [[Lucien Favre]]'s [[Borussia Mönchengladbach]]. After medical checks were completed, Xhaka signed a five-year deal with the club. The transfer fee was not disclosed by Mönchengladbach, but is estimated to be in the region of €8.5 million.<ref name="fcb4">{{cite web |url=http://www.fcb.ch/news/show/byItemID/de-de/10044/27987/26/7/7 | archive-url = https://archive.is/20130101110223/http://www.fcb.ch/news/show/byItemID/de-de/10044/27987/26/7/7 | dead-url = yes | archive-date = 1 January 2013 |title=Granit Xhaka wechselt im Sommer vom FCB zu Borussia Mönchengladbach |publisher=FC Basel 1893 |accessdate=18 May 2012 |language=German |date=18 May 2012}}</ref>
Xhaka made his debut in a [[2012–13 DFB-Pokal|DFB-Pokal]] first round match against [[Alemannia Aachen]] on 18 August 2012. Three days later, he made his first appearance in European competition for Borussia in 1–3 home lost to [[FC Dynamo Kyiv|Dynamo Kyiv]] in qualification for the [[2012–13 UEFA Champions League]]. On 25 August, he made his Bundesliga debut in the team's opening match of [[2012–13 Bundesliga|the season]], a 2–1 home win against [[TSG 1899 Hoffenheim|1899 Hoffenheim]]. He scored his first and only goal of the season in a 3–2 loss at [[1. FC Nürnberg]].<ref name=kicker>{{cite news |url=http://www.kicker.de/news/fussball/bundesliga/vereine/2012-13/57343/vereinsspieler_xhaka-granit.html |title=Granit Xhaka |accessdate=31 March 2016 |work=kicker}}</ref>
In his second season at the club, Xhaka started 29 times and made five substitute appearances as Gladbach finished in sixth place in the [[2014–15 Bundesliga|Bundesliga]].<ref name=kicker/>
In 2014–15, Xhaka started all 34 [[2014–15 Bundesliga|Bundesliga]] matches for Borussia<ref name=kicker/> and was named in the league's team of the season.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.bundesliga.de/de/liga/news/infografik-die-top-11-der-saison.jsp |title=Infografik: Die Top-11 der Saison 2014/15 |date=25 May 2015 |work=Bundesliga}}</ref> Borussia finished in third place to qualify for the [[2015–16 UEFA Champions League]].
On 23 September 2015, Xhaka captained Borussia and scored his first goal of the season, heading in from [[Raffael (footballer)|Raffael]]'s free kick in a 4–2 win over [[FC Augsburg]]. In the next match, against [[VfB Stuttgart]], Xhaka again captained the side and scored a goal in a 3–1 win. On 30 September, he made his first appearance for Borussia in the Champions League proper in a 1–2 [[2015–16 UEFA Champions League group stage|group stage]] loss at home to [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]].<ref name=kicker/> Xhaka received his fifth red card for the team in his 95th game on 20 December, for striking his opponent in the first half; he voluntarily gave €20,000 to charity as an apology.<ref>{{cite news |title=Granit Xhaka pays his dues after Gladbach star racks up red cards |url=http://www.espnfc.co.uk/blog/the-toe-poke/65/post/2767083/gladbach-xhaka-pays-after-red-cards |accessdate=11 June 2016 |publisher=ESPN FC |date=22 December 2015}}</ref>
===Arsenal=== On 25 May 2016, [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] signed Xhaka from Borussia Mönchengladbach for a fee of around £30–35 million.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-3608536/Granit-Xhaka-signs-Arsenal-35m-deal-Arsene-Wenger-admits-club-tracking-Swiss-midfielder-long-time.html |title=Granit Xhaka signs for Arsenal in £35m deal as Arsene Wenger admits club have been tracking Swiss midfielder 'for a long time' |work=Daily Mail |date=25 May 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Granit Xhaka signs for Arsenal: Gunners complete deal for Swiss international midfielder |url=https://www.standard.co.uk/sport/football/granit-xhaka-signs-for-arsenal-gunners-complete-deal-for-swiss-international-midfielder-a3251411.html |newspaper=London Evening Standard |first=James |last=Benge |date=25 May 2016 |accessdate=25 May 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |title=Arsenal will pay around £30m for Granit Xhaka, Sky Sports News HQ understands |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11670/10290914/arsenal-will-pay-around-16330m-for-granit-xhaka-sky-sports-news-hq-understands |publisher=Sky Sports |date=22 May 2016 |accessdate=25 May 2016}}</ref> Xhaka made his first appearance for Arsenal (as a half-time substitution) in a 2–1 win against the [[MLS All-Stars]].<ref>{{Cite news |title=MLS All-Stars 1–2 Arsenal – Report |url=https://www.arsenal.com/match/report/1617/post/first-team/mls-all-stars-1-2-arsenal-report |publisher=Arsenal F.C. |date=29 July 2016 |accessdate=30 July 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.premierleague.com/players/12136/Granit-Xhaka/overview |title=Granit Xhaka Profile |publisher=Premier League |accessdate=25 April 2018}}</ref>
Xhaka made his competitive debut for Arsenal in the club's opening match of the [[2016–17 Premier League]] season, a 4–3 defeat to [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]], replacing midfielder [[Mohamed Elneny]] in the 65th minute while also picking up a yellow card in the process.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/live/football/36741050 |title=FT: Arsenal 3–4 Liverpool |publisher=BBC |accessdate=24 September 2016}}</ref> His first goal for the club came on 17 September 2016, a 25-yard thunderbolt in a 4–1 [[Premier League]] victory against [[Hull City A.F.C.|Hull City]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://m.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/37326798 |title=Hull City 1–4 Arsenal |publisher=BBC Sport |date=17 September 2016 |accessdate=17 September 2016}}</ref> Four days later, he would score again from distance, this time from 30 yards in a 4–0 [[2016–17 EFL Cup|EFL Cup]] defeat of [[Nottingham Forest F.C.|Nottingham Forest]].<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/fa-league-cups/nottingham-forest-vs-arsenal-match-report-granit-xhaka-goal-lucas-perez-arsene-wenger-result-efl-cup-a7319556.html |title=Nottingham Forest vs Arsenal report: Granit Xhaka and Lucas Perez give Arsene Wenger plenty to smile about |date=21 September 2016 |work=The Independent}}</ref> Xhaka's first Arsenal red card – and eighth for club and country since April 2014 – came in a 3–2 win over [[Swansea City A.F.C.|Swansea City]] on 15 October 2016.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/37594169 |title=Arsenal 3–2 Swansea City |publisher=BBC |accessdate=24 September 2016}}</ref> On 22 January 2017, Xhaka was sent off for the second time in the season, by referee [[Jonathan Moss (referee)|Jon Moss]], in Arsenal's 2–1 home win against [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]].<ref>{{cite news |last1=Skelton |first1=Jack |title=Arsenal 2–1 Burnley |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/38626832 |accessdate=22 January 2017 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=22 January 2017}}</ref> After his first goal for the club in September, he would not score in the Premier League again until doing so in May, scoring the first goal of a 2–0 victory over [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]], ending United's run of 25 consecutive games unbeaten.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/39760508 |title=Arsenal 2–0 Manchester United |publisher=BBC Sport |date=7 May 2017 |accessdate=7 May 2017}}</ref>
Xhaka went on to feature throughout Arsenal's triumphant [[2016-17 FA Cup|FA Cup campaign]]. As so he started in the [[2017 FA Cup Final|Cup final]] against [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] which the Gunners won 2–1.<ref name=FACup>{{cite web |url=https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=WXeS3rsW1Z8 |title=Arsenal 2–1 Chelsea – Emirates FA Cup Final 2016/17 |via=YouTube |publisher=FATV}}</ref> Xhaka also played in the [[2017 FA Community Shield|2017 Community Shield]] that Arsenal won on penalties over Chelsea.<ref name=CS>{{cite web |url=https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=sVwr6MxovYQ |title=Arsenal 1–1 Chelsea (4–1 Pens) – FA Community Shield |via=YouTube |publisher=FATV}}</ref> His first goal of the 2017–18 season came in a 3–3 draw with Liverpool, Xhaka scored a 25-yard thunderbolt to take Arsenal from 2–1 to 2–2.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/42362392 |title=Arsenal 3–3 Liverpool |publisher=BBC |date=22 December 2017 |accessdate=9 January 2018}}</ref>
On 15 September 2018, Xhaka scored the first goal, from a direct free kick, in a 2–1 victory against [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/sep/15/newcastle-arsenal-premier-league-report|title=Arsenal’s Mesut Özil leaves Ciaran Clark and Newcastle too much to do|last=Taylor|first=Louise|date=15 September 2018|website=The Guardian|access-date=29 October 2018}}</ref> On 28 October 2018, he scored again from a free kick against [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/oct/28/crystal-palace-arsenal-premier-league-match-report|title=Crystal Palace’s Luka Milivojevic holds his nerve to end Arsenal’s winning run|last=Fifield|first=Dominic|date=28 October 2018|website=The Guardian|access-date=29 October 2018}}</ref>
==International career== ===Switzerland youth squads=== Xhaka has played for Swiss youth squad at the U-17 level. He participated in the [[FIFA U-17 World Cup|Under-17 World Cup]] in [[2009 FIFA U-17 World Cup|2009 in Nigeria]]. The Swiss team won the World Cup.<ref name= "Player statistics FIFA U17 World Cup">{{cite web |title=Player statistics FIFA U17 World Cup |url=https://www.fifa.com/worldfootball/statisticsandrecords/players/player=311558/index.html |publisher=FIFA |accessdate=29 August 2010}}</ref>
He played his first game for the [[Switzerland national under-19 football team]] on 25 May 2010, as a substitute, as the team beat [[Austria national under-19 football team]] 3–2 in the [[Schwaz]], Austria. He scored his first goal for the U-19 on 7 September 2010 as the team won 3–0 against the [[Czech Republic national under-19 football team|Czech Republic]].
===Switzerland under-21=== Xhaka played his first game for the [[Switzerland national under-21 football team|under-21 side]] on 3 September 2010, as a substitute, as the team beat the [[Republic of Ireland under-21 national football team|Republic of Ireland]] 1–0 at the [[Cornaredo Stadium]] in [[Lugano]].<ref name=" Match report Switzerland 1-0 Republic of Ireland ">{{cite web |last=UEFA.com |year=2010 |url=http://www.uefa.com/under21/matches/season=2011/round=2000006/match=2000066/index.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100816061752/http://www.uefa.com/under21/matches/season%3D2011/round%3D2000006/match%3D2000066/index.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=16 August 2010 |title=Switzerland see off Ireland for play-off place |publisher=UEFA |accessdate=3 September 2010}}</ref> This was the last game in the [[2011 UEFA European Under-21 Football Championship qualification Group 2|qualification Group 2]] to the [[2011 UEFA European Under-21 Football Championship]]. Xhaka was member of the Swiss U-21 squad that competed in the final tournament, hosted by Denmark, between 11 and 25 June 2011. The Swiss team reached the final without conceding a goal, but lost to [[Spain national under-21 football team|Spain]] 2–0.
===Switzerland senior team=== [[File:Suisse vs Argentine - Granit Xhaka & Lionel Messi.jpg|thumb|right|Xhaka (left) challenging [[Lionel Messi]] for the ball during an [[Exhibition match|international friendly]] between [[Switzerland national football team|Switzerland]] and [[Argentina national football team|Argentina]] on 29 February 2012.]] Before making his international debut for [[Switzerland national football team|Switzerland]], Xhaka was still undecided whether to play for his birth country or [[Albania national football team|Albania]], and he complained to the Albanian sports media that [[FSHF]] was ignoring him while the Swiss Football Association was showing much more interest.<ref name=Albaniasoccer1>{{cite news |last=Begu |first=Yll |title=Në fokus / Granit Xhaka: Dua të luaj për Shqipërinë, por mungon interesimi i FSHF-së! |url=http://www.albaniasoccer.com/lajme/shqiperi/kombetarja/4627-ne-fokus--granit-xhaka-dua-te-luaj-per-shqiperine-por-mungon-interesimi-i-fshf-se.html |date=13 April 2011 |quote="Mesfushori i Bazelit, Granit Xhaka, së bashku me vëllanë e tij, Taulantin, kanë dëshirë për t'u bërë pjesë e kombëtares shqiptare, mirëpo deri më tash nuk kanë parë kurrfarë interesimi nga Federata Shqiptare e Futbollit që t'i afrojë ata në kombëtaren kuqezi.", further in the article Xhaka says: "“Në javët e fundit është bërë një presion i madh drejt nesh nga mediet lokale për të zgjedhur kombëtaren e Zvicrës dhe e kam të vështirë ta kuptoj përse askush nga FSHF-ja nuk ka reaguar për të shprehur interesim që ne të vishemi kuqezi”, ka theksuar Granit Xhaka.}}</ref>
Xhaka debuted for Switzerland at [[Wembley Stadium]] against [[England national football team|England]] in a 2–2 [[UEFA Euro 2012 qualification]] draw on 4 June 2011.<ref name="Fulldebut">{{cite web |url=http://football.uk.reuters.com/leagues/uk/news/2011/06/04/LDE7530D0.php | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20120311104620/http://football.uk.reuters.com/leagues/uk/news/2011/06/04/LDE7530D0.php | dead-url = yes | archive-date = 11 March 2012 |title=Below-par England salvage draw with Switzerland |agency=Reuters |date=4 June 2011 |accessdate=5 June 2011 |last=Collett |first=Mike}}</ref> On 15 November 2011, during his sixth international appearance, he scored his first international goal in the 1–0 away win against [[Luxembourg national football team|Luxembourg]] at the [[Stade Josy Barthel]].<ref name="sfv 3">{{cite web |year=2011 |url=http://www.football.ch/nm/de/A_Team-telegramm.aspx?tg=1921952 | archive-url = https://archive.is/20130115214415/http://www.football.ch/nm/de/A_Team-telegramm.aspx?tg=1921952 | dead-url = yes | archive-date = 15 January 2013 |title=Matchtelegram Luxembourg-Schweiz |publisher=football.ch |accessdate=15 November 2011 |language=German}}</ref>
Switzerland also tried to select Xhaka to participate in the [[Football at the 2012 Summer Olympics - Men's tournament|2012 Olympic Football tournament]], but he opted to stay at his new club for pre-season training.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/07/09/oly-socc-swiss-squad-idUSB29215720120709 |title=Olympics-Shaqiri, Xhaka excluded from Swiss soccer squad |agency=Reuters |date=9 July 2012 |accessdate=27 July 2012}}</ref> He participated in all ten of Switzerland's [[2014 FIFA World Cup qualification (UEFA)|2014 FIFA World Cup qualification campaign]] matches, scoring both goals in a 2–0 defeat of [[Slovenia national football team|Slovenia]].<ref name=fifa>{{cite news |url=https://www.fifa.com/worldcup/players/player=311558/played-matches.html |title=Granit XHAKA |accessdate=21 June 2014 |publisher=FIFA}}</ref> On 2 June 2014, Xhaka was named in Switzerland's [[2014 FIFA World Cup|2014 World Cup]] squad by national coach [[Ottmar Hitzfeld]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/switzerland/10810381/Switzerland-World-Cup-2014-squad.html |title=Switzerland World Cup 2014 squad |date=2 June 2014 |accessdate=16 June 2014 |work=The Telegraph}}</ref> In the team's second match, Xhaka scored in a 5–2 loss to [[France national football team|France]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/25285207 |title=Switzerland 2–5 France |date=20 June 2014 |accessdate=21 June 2014 |publisher=BBC}}</ref>
Xhaka was selected for [[UEFA Euro 2016|Euro 2016]], where Switzerland's campaign opened against Albania in [[Lens, Pas-de-Calais|Lens]]. Xhaka, whose team won 1–0, was playing against his brother [[Taulant Xhaka|Taulant]] while their mother watched from the crowd in a T-shirt blending the two nations' flags.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Gill |first1=Kieran |title=Granit and Taulant Xhaka go head to head at Euro 2016... as their mother wears a half-and-half Switzerland-Albania shirt and older brother throws a tantrum on the touchline |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-3636643/Granit-Taulant-Xhaka-head-head-Euro-2016-mother-wears-half-half-Switzerland-Albania-shirt-older-brother-throws-tantrum-touchline.html |accessdate=11 June 2016 |work=Daily Mail |date=11 June 2016}}</ref> He was voted the [[man of the match]].<ref>{{cite news |last1=Atkin |first1=John |title=Switzerland hold on against ten-man Albania |url=http://www.uefa.com/uefaeuro/season=2016/matches/round=2000448/match=2017878/postmatch/report/index.html |accessdate=25 June 2016 |publisher=UEFA |date=11 June 2016}}</ref> Xhaka played every minute of Switzerland's campaign, which ended in the round of 16 with a loss to [[Poland national football team|Poland]] at the [[Stade Geoffroy-Guichard]]; after a 1–1 draw he was the only player to not score in the [[penalty shoot-out (association football)|penalty shootout]], shooting wide.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Brassell |first1=Andy |title=Poland hold nerve after Switzerland's Granit Xhaka blazes penalty wide |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/jun/25/switzerland-poland-euro-2016-match-report |accessdate=25 June 2016 |work=The Guardian |date=25 June 2016}}</ref>
Ahead of the [[2018 FIFA World Cup qualification (UEFA)|2018 World Cup qualifiers]], there was speculation that Xhaka could switch his allegiance to represent [[Kosovo national football team|Kosovo]], which had been accepted as a full member of [[FIFA]] and were allowed to play competitive matches for the first time. Xhaka, however, published an open letter stating that his participation in Euro 2016 had disqualified him from changing his allegiance, and he was thus tied to Switzerland.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://talentet.eu/2016/08/30/leter-e-hapur-nga-granit-xhaka/ |title=Letër e hapur nga Granit XHAKA – TALENTËT |website=talentet.eu|access-date=6 September 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160905024345/http://talentet.eu/2016/08/30/leter-e-hapur-nga-granit-xhaka/|archive-date=5 September 2016|dead-url=yes}}</ref>
Xhaka was named in manager [[Vladimir Petković]]'s 23-man Swiss squad for the [[2018 FIFA World Cup]] in Russia.<ref>{{cite news |title=2018 World Cup: Switzerland name Granit Xhaka and Xherdan Shaqiri in squad |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/44360966 |accessdate=22 June 2018 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=4 June 2018}}</ref> On 22 June, he equalised with a long-range strike as the Swiss came from behind to defeat [[Serbia national football team|Serbia]] 2–1 in their second game. He and fellow goalscorer [[Xherdan Shaqiri]], who is also of Kosovar descent, [[Goal celebration|celebrated their goals]] by making an [[Crossed hands (gesture)|eagle gesture]] resembling the double headed eagle of the [[Albanian flag]].<ref>{{cite news |last1=Lowe |first1=Sid |title=Switzerland’s Xherdan Shaqiri stuns Serbia with late breakaway |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/jun/22/serbia-switzerland-xherdan-shaqiri-world-cup-group-e-match-report |accessdate=22 June 2018 |work=The Guardian |date=22 June 2018 |quote=As he turned and screamed, he took his shirt off, flexed his muscles and performed a double-eagle celebration, a recreation of the Albanian flag. Alongside him, Granit Xhaka did the same – for the second time.}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Swiss duo's 'provocative' black eagle goal celebration 'mixes sport and politics' |url=https://edition.cnn.com/2018/06/23/football/xherdan-shaqiri-granit-xhaka-eagle-goal-celebration-serbia-switzerland-world-cup-spt-intl/index.html |accessdate=25 June 2018 |publisher=CNN |date=24 June 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Switzerland's Xhaka and Shaqiri charged by Fifa over Serbia goal celebrations |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/jun/23/xhaka-and-shaqiri-goal-celebrations-bring-balkan-politics-to-world-cup |accessdate=24 June 2018 |work=The Guardian |date=25 June 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=World Cup 2018: Xherdan Shaqiri and Granit Xhaka’s controversial goal celebrations criticised by Swiss media |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/world-cup/world-cup-2018-switzerland-serbia-granit-xhaka-xherdan-shaqiri-goal-celebrations-why-controversial-a8413426.html |accessdate=25 June 2018 |work=The Guardian |date=23 June 2018}}</ref> FIFA fined each player 10,000 [[Swiss franc]]s "for unsporting behaviour contrary to the principles of fair-play".<ref>{{cite news |title=World Cup 2018: Switzerland trio avoid bans for 'eagle gesture' goal celebrations |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/44606965 |accessdate=25 June 2018 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=25 June 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=World Cup 2018: Granit Xhaka and Xherdan Shaqiri avoid bans after political goal celebrations |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/world-cup/world-cup-2018-granit-xhaka-xherdan-shaqiri-goal-celebrations-albania-kosovo-serbia-fine-a8416466.html |accessdate=25 June 2018 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=25 June 2018}}</ref>
==Personal life== In July 2017, Xhaka married his long-term partner, Leonita Lekaj.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/news/granit-xhaka-married-leonita-lekaj-10753757 |title=Arsenal star Granit Xhaka marries long-term partner Leonita Lekaj as team-mates return for pre-season training |date=7 July 2017 |accessdate=11 January 2018 |work=Daily Mirror}}</ref>

revision.comment: undo, per sources cited, which are consistent with birth records; the date at https://www.arsenal.com/academy/players/cohen-bramall would appear to be a typo
revision.text:
{{Infobox football biography | name = Cohen Bramall | image = | image_size = | caption = | fullname = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1996|4|2|df=y}}{{cite web |url=https://www.premierleague.com/players/21627/Cohen-Bramall/overview |title=Cohen Bramall: Overview |publisher=Premier League |accessdate=27 February 2019 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20190227191141/https://www.premierleague.com/players/21627/Cohen-Bramall/overview |archivedate=27 February 2019}} | birth_place = [[Crewe]], England | height = {{convert|1.75|m|order=flip}} | currentclub = [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] | clubnumber = 39 | position = [[Left back]] | youthyears1 = | youthclubs1 = | years1 = 2013–2014 | clubs1 = [[Kidsgrove Athletic F.C.|Kidsgrove Athletic]] | caps1 = | goals1 = | years2 = 2014 | clubs2 = → [[Alsager Town F.C.|Alsager Town]] (dual registration) | caps2 = | goals2 = | years3 = 2014 | clubs3 = [[Nantwich Town F.C.|Nantwich Town]] | caps3 = | goals3 = | years4 = 2014 | clubs4 = [[Market Drayton Town F.C.|Market Drayton Town]] | caps4 = | goals4 = | years5 = 2014–2015 | clubs5 = [[Newcastle Town F.C.|Newcastle Town]] | caps5 = | goals5 = | years6 = 2015–2016 | clubs6 = [[Market Drayton Town F.C.|Market Drayton Town]] | caps6 = | goals6 = | years7 = 2016–2017 | clubs7 = [[Hednesford Town F.C.|Hednesford Town]] | caps7 = 21 | goals7 = 0 | years8 = 2017– | clubs8 = [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] | caps8 = 0 | goals8 = 0 | years9 = 2017–2018 | clubs9 = → [[Birmingham City F.C.|Birmingham City]] (loan) | caps9 = 5 | goals9 = 0 | nationalyears1 = | nationalteam1 = | nationalcaps1 = | nationalgoals1 = | club-update = 10:01, 7 May 2018 (UTC) | nationalteam-update = }} '''Cohen Bramall''' (born 2 April 1996) is an English professional [[association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[left back]] for {{English football updater|Arsenal}} club [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]]. He spent the 2017–18 season on loan to [[Birmingham City F.C.|Birmingham City]] of the [[EFL Championship|Championship]]. ==Life and career== ===Early life and career=== Bramall was born in [[Crewe]], Cheshire.{{cite web |url=https://www.bcfc.com/birmingham-city/players/cohen-bramall/ |title=Cohen Bramall |publisher=Birmingham City F.C. |accessdate=23 August 2017 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170823163657/https://www.bcfc.com/birmingham-city/players/cohen-bramall/ |archivedate=23 August 2017}} He began his career in [[non-League football]] in his local area, with [[Kidsgrove Athletic F.C.|Kidsgrove Athletic]], [[Alsager Town F.C.|Alsager Town]], [[Nantwich Town F.C.|Nantwich Town]], [[Market Drayton Town F.C.|Market Drayton Town]]{{snd}}with whom he won the 2015–16 Shropshire Premier Cup in his second spell at the club{{cite web |url=http://www.pitchero.com/clubs/marketdraytontown/teams/24359/match-centre/0-3304430 |title=Drayton win T J Vickers Cup in penalty shoot out |first=Cliff |last=Taylor |publisher=Market Drayton Town F.C. |date=3 May 2016 |accessdate=11 September 2017}}
{{cite news |url=https://www.shropshirestar.com/sport/non-league/2016/05/04/market-drayton-take-home-the-premier-cup/ |title=Market Drayton take home the Premier Cup |newspaper=Shropshire Star |date=4 May 2016 |accessdate=11 September 2017}}{{snd}}and [[Newcastle Town F.C.|Newcastle Town]].{{cite web |url=http://www.pitmenweb.com/playerprofilebramall.htm |title=Cohen Bramall: Defence/Midfield |website=PitmenWeb |accessdate=23 August 2017}} In May 2016, he moved to [[Northern Premier League]] Premier Division club [[Hednesford Town F.C.|Hednesford Town]]. He played on a part-time basis while working at a [[Bentley]] car factory.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/38572994 |title=Cohen Bramall: Arsenal sign non-league left-back |date=10 January 2017 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=22 August 2017}} Bramall was first offered a trial with [[EFL Championship|Championship]] club [[Sheffield Wednesday F.C.|Sheffield Wednesday]], appearing with their under-23 side in a match.{{cite news |url=http://www.birminghammail.co.uk/sport/football/transfer-news/cohen-bramall-birmingham-city-arsenal-13506256 |title=Factory worker, rabonas and Arsenal – meet Birmingham City new boy Cohen Bramall |first=Alex |last=Dicken |newspaper=Birmingham Mail |date=21 August 2017 |accessdate=22 August 2017}} [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] of the [[Premier League]] were also interested in signing him. ===Arsenal=== After a short trial, Bramall signed professional forms with Premier League club [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] on 9 January 2017.{{cite web |url=https://www.arsenal.com/news/news-archive/20170109/cohen-bramall-joins-arsenal-under-23s |title=Cohen Bramall joins club as young pro |publisher=Arsenal F.C. |date=9 January 2017 |accessdate=15 August 2017}} The fee was officially undisclosed,{{cite web |url=http://www.hednesfordtownfc.com/2017/01/cohen-bramall-makes-arsenal-move |title=Cohen Bramall makes Arsenal move |publisher=Hednesford Town F.C. |date=10 January 2017 |accessdate=25 August 2017}} but was widely reported as around £40,000.{{cite news |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11670/10717289/arsenal-to-sign-hednesford-defender-cohen-bramall-sky-sources |title=Arsenal to sign Hednesford defender Cohen Bramall – Sky sources |publisher=Sky Sports |date=4 January 2017 |accessdate=25 August 2017}}
{{cite news |url=https://www.expressandstar.com/sport/football/non-league/hednesford-town-fc/2017/01/10/hednesford-town-youngster-cohen-bramall-officially-joins-arsenal/ |title=Hednesford Town youngster Cohen Bramall officially joins Arsenal |newspaper=Express & Star |location=Wolverhampton |date=10 January 2017 |accessdate=25 August 2017}} He spent the remainder of the season playing for the club's [[Arsenal F.C. Reserves|under-23]] side. During Arsenal's pre-season before the [[2017–18 Premier League|2017–18 season]], Bramall joined the first-team squad for the club's tour of Australia and China, making his senior debut in a friendly against [[A-League]] side [[Sydney F.C.|Sydney]]. ====Birmingham City (loan)==== On 21 August 2017, Bramall and Arsenal teammate [[Carl Jenkinson]] were [[loan (sports)|loaned]] to Championship club [[Birmingham City F.C.|Birmingham City]] until the end of the season.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/41000686 |title=Birmingham loan Arsenal's Carl Jenkinson and Cohen Bramall plus Southampton's Sam Gallagher |publisher=BBC Sport |date=21 August 2017 |accessdate=22 August 2017}} Bramall made his senior professional debut the next day in Birmingham's starting eleven for their [[EFL Cup]] match against [[A.F.C. Bournemouth|Bournemouth]]. He played 78 minutes in a 2–1 defeat.{{cite news |url=http://www.birminghammail.co.uk/sport/football/transfer-news/heres-how-birmingham-citys-arsenal-13515491 |title=Here's how Birmingham City's Arsenal loanee Cohen Bramall did on his professional debut |first=Alex |last=Dicken |newspaper=Birmingham Mail |date=23 August 2017 |accessdate=23 August 2017}} He made his first [[English Football League|Football League]] appearance in Birmingham's next match, playing the whole of a 2–0 defeat at home to [[Reading F.C.|Reading]]. That was his last appearance until December, when, with central defenders [[Harlee Dean]] suspended and [[Marc Roberts (footballer)|Marc Roberts]] injured, he started at left wing-back in a 1–0 loss away to [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]].{{cite news |url=https://www.birminghammail.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/fulham-v-birmingham-city-arsenal-14015944 |title=Fulham v Birmingham City: Arsenal loan man comes into makeshift defence at Craven Cottage |first=Brian |last=Dick |newspaper=Birmingham Mail |date=9 December 2018 |accessdate=7 May 2018}} Despite speculation that the loan might be cut short in the January transfer window,{{cite news |url=https://www.birminghammail.co.uk/sport/football/transfer-news/cohen-bramall-carl-jenkinson-birmingham-14113518 |title=Cohen Bramall and Carl Jenkinson: Birmingham City boss Steve Cotterill on the Arsenal duo's futures |first=Brian |last=Dick |newspaper=Birmingham Mail |date=5 February 2018 |accessdate=7 May 2018}} he remained at the club, and returned to the league team on 3 February, as a substitute for the injured [[Jonathan Grounds]] in a 3–1 win away to [[Sheffield Wednesday]]. He was involved in an incident for which Wednesday's [[Marco Matias (footballer)|Marco Matias]] was sent off for violent conduct. Former referee [[Mark Halsey]] said afterwards that if there had been a dismissable offence, it was committed by Bramall,{{cite news |url=https://www.birminghammail.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/referee-got-wrong-man-birmingham-14250737 |title=Referee 'got the wrong man' in Birmingham City's win at Sheffield Wednesday – ex Premier League official |first=Shane |last=Ireland |newspaper=Birmingham Mail |date=5 February 2018 |accessdate=7 May 2018}} and Matias' red card was rescinded on appeal.{{cite news |url=https://www.thestar.co.uk/sport/football/sheffield-wednesday/sheffield-wednesday-win-appeal-over-marco-matias-red-card-against-birmingham-city-1-9005473 |title=Sheffield Wednesday win appeal over Marco Matias' red card against Birmingham City |first=Chris |last=Holt |newspaper=The Star |location=Sheffield |date=6 February 2018 |accessdate=7 May 2018}} Bramall played in two more Championship matches in February, but those were his last. ==Career statistics== {{updated|end of 2017–18 season}} {| class=wikitable style=text-align:center |- !rowspan=2|Club !rowspan=2|Season !colspan=3|League !colspan=2|[[FA Cup]] !colspan=2|[[EFL Cup]] !colspan=2|Other !colspan=2|Total |- !Division!!Apps!!Goals!!Apps!!Goals!!Apps!!Goals!!Apps!!Goals!!Apps!!Goals |- |[[Hednesford Town F.C.|Hednesford Town]] |[[2016–17 Northern Premier League#Premier Division|2016–17]]{{cite web |url=http://hednesfordtown.com/statistics/player.php?sort=apps&id=452 |title=Cohen Bramall profile |website=hednesfordtown.com |publisher=Steve Walker |accessdate=2 September 2017 |archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20170902142221/http://hednesfordtown.com/statistics/player.php?sort=apps&id=452 |archivedate=2 September 2017}} |[[Northern Premier League]] Premier Division||21||0||1||1||colspan=2|—||4{{efn|Three appearances in [[FA Trophy]], one in [[Birmingham Senior Cup]]}}||0||26||1 |- |rowspan=1|[[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] |[[2017–18 Arsenal F.C. season|2017–18]] |[[Premier League]]||0||0||colspan=2|—||colspan=2|—||colspan=2|—||0||0 |- |[[Birmingham City F.C.|Birmingham City]] (loan) |[[2017–18 Birmingham City F.C. season|2017–18]]{{soccerbase season|104461|2017|accessdate=7 May 2018}} |[[EFL Championship|Championship]]||5||0||2||0||1||0||colspan=2|—||8||0 |- !colspan=3|Career total !26||0||3||1||1||0||4||0||34||1 |} {{notelist}} ==Honours== '''Market Drayton Town''' *Shropshire Premier Cup: 2015–16 ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{Soccerway}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2017}} {{Infobox soap character | image = Dom thompson.jpg | imagesize = 200px | name = Dominic Thompson | series = [[Shortland Street]] | portrayer = [[Shane Cortese]] | first = 13 February 2003 | last = 2 December 2004 | gender = Male | alias = | age = | classification = [[List of Shortland Street characters#Current characters|Former; regular]] | born = | death = 2 December 2004 | introducer = Harriet Crampton | years = 2003–04 | home = | occupation = Physiotherapist | family = | wife= [[Emily Bredican]] (2003–04) | father= Anthony Thompson | mother= [[Ngaire Thompson]] | halfbrothers= | sisters= [[Toni Warner]] | daughters= | sons= | romances= | granddaughters= | grandsons= | grandfathers= | grandmothers= | nephews= [[Harry Warner (Shortland Street)|Harry Warner]]
James Warner | nieces= | aunts= | uncles= }} '''Dominic "Dom" Thompson''' is a fictional character on the [[New Zealand]] [[soap opera]] ''[[Shortland Street]]'' who was portrayed by [[Shane Cortese]] from 2003 to 2004. Dom arrived as the brother of established character [[Toni Thompson]] (Laura Hill) however soon after arrival, was revealed as the half brother of [[Chris Warner]] ([[Michael Galvin]]). Initially appearing as a protagonist, Dom soon developed into a much more sinister character who was key to several high-profile storylines. These included his marriage to [[Emily Bredican]] (Sarah Somerville), affair with 16-year-old [[Delphi Greenlaw]] ([[Anna Hutchison]]), a rivalry with Chris Warner after discovering they were not related, murdering [[Geoff Greenlaw]] ([[Andrew Laing]]), his controversial return on the shows 3000th episode, his murder of Avril Lucich (Kate Louise-Elliott) and a dramatic conclusion episode in December 2004 that saw Dom die after trying to murder Chris. Dom's two-year-long stint saw the show receive huge ratings and the period be remembered as a well done and iconic season. The character remains mentioned and referred to as a menacing and monumental character who brought the show back its excitement. ==Creation and casting== After auditioning for Geoff Greenlaw and losing out to [[Andrew Laing]], [[Shane Cortese]] learned producers had created a character specifically for him to be the brother of a major character and it was undecided whether the character would be "good or bad".{{cite web|work=NZonscreen |title=Shane Cortese on being a badguy |date=March 2011|publisher=[[NZ On Air]]|author=Coleman, James|url=http://screentalk.nzonscreen.com/interviews/shane-cortese}} Cortese made his debut as Dom in early 2003 under a yearlong contract with the potential of another 12 month expansion. The character stayed on screen for a year and departed in early 2004. Producers offered Cortese the chance to return on the show's 3000th episode under a contract that would see him continue with the show until mid-2005.{{cite news|title=Playing Shortland Street's scumbag isn't all good fun|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/lifestyle/news/article.cfm?c_id=6&objectid=3580666|work=[[The New Zealand Herald]]|date=July 2004|accessdate=1 November 2011|author=Barry, Rebecca|publisher=[[APN News & Media]]}} Cortese accepted and returned to the show on the momentous 3000th episode.{{cite news|title=What a nasty surprise for amorous Dr Warner|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/lifestyle/news/article.cfm?c_id=6&objectid=3574399|work=[[The New Zealand Herald]]|author=Grant, Frances|publisher=[[APN News & Media]]|date=24 June 2004}} The character ended up getting killed off later in the year.{{cite news|title=Return to the shaky aisles on Shortland Street|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/lifestyle/news/article.cfm?c_id=6&objectid=9003160|work=[[The New Zealand Herald]]|date=December 2004|accessdate=1 November 2011|publisher=[[APN News & Media]]|author=Barry, Rebecca}} ==Storylines== Dom arrived to visit his sister [[Toni Warner|Toni]] (Laura Hill) and quickly got a job at the hospital. He mysteriously got on well with rival [[Chris Warner|Chris]]' ([[Michael Galvin]]) mother - [[Margot Warner]] (Dinah Priestley) and when she died, Dom revealed himself as Chris' illegitimate half brother. Taking up the Warner surname, Dom married [[Emily Bredican|Emily]] (Sarah Somerville) and fought attractions to teenager - [[Delphi Greenlaw]] ([[Anna Hutchison]]). Following a blood test, Dom realized he was not related to Chris but kept it a secret whilst he started an affair with Delphi. To hide the affair, he drugged his wife and soon became a suspect in the murder of [[Geoff Greenlaw|Geoff]] ([[Andrew Laing]]) who had discovered the affair. Once Chris discovered the truth, Dom circulated rumours he was a child molestor. Dom and Delphi planned to run away but Delphi discovered Dom had killed Geoff and a desperate Dom fled Ferndale. Dom returned later in 2004, having started a relationship with [[Lucy Swinton|Lucy]] (Sally Stockwell). He managed to successfully avoid capture in relation to Geoff's murder and when [[Avril Lucich|Avril]] (Kate Louise-Elliot) began snooping, he drowned her in his bath tub. When the staff started to turn against Dom after Avril's sister [[Bernadette Lucich|Bernadette]] (Kate Louise-Elliot) accused him of murder, he faked mental illness and after escaping a psych ward, he lured Chris to a barn and tried to set him on fire. Unsuccessful, Dom ended up getting caught in a large explosion. With intense burns, Dom finally admitted to killing Geoff and Avril before he died in Toni's arms. ==Character development== ===Relationship with Delphi Greenlaw=== In 2003 Dom underwent a storyline where he fell for his best friends sister, 15-year-old [[Delphi Greenlaw]]. Cortese was at first uncomfortable with the storyline, stating; "I was very worried about the age difference but the way it's been done and written is really respectful."{{cite news|title=More suds in the soap|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/lifestyle/news/article.cfm?c_id=6&objectid=3451964|work=[[The New Zealand Herald]]|date=May 2003|accessdate=1 November 2011|author=Grant, Frances|publisher=[[APN News & Media]]}} Cortese also believed despite the age difference, Dom was truly in love with Delphi; "Dom sees Delphi as his soul mate, she affects him in a way no one has before because he's always been suspicious of relationships. He doesn't have to pretend to be anyone else for her to like him." Producer Harriet Crampton enjoyed the romance and how it contrasted with Dom's evil character, stating; "To have a villain who has a strong sincere love or passion makes you think, ‘Okay, he’s an absolute bastard but we know he does love Delphi." The two first get together when Delphi turns 16, sharing a kiss.{{cite news|title=Powerpoint: Back on the home front|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/lifestyle/news/article.cfm?c_id=6&objectid=3351598|work=[[The New Zealand Herald]]|publisher=[[APN News & Media]]|date=10 April 2003}} The two eventually start a relationship but break up when Dom comes under question of Geoff's murder in arguably one of the soap's most memorable storylines.{{cite news|title=Soapland echoes to sounds of wailing|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/lifestyle/news/article.cfm?c_id=6&objectid=3533134|work=[[The New Zealand Herald]]|date=November 2003|accessdate=1 November 2011|author=Dixon, Greg|publisher=[[APN News & Media]]}}{{cite news|title=Big bangs, and a few whimpers on telly in 2003|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/lifestyle/news/article.cfm?c_id=6&objectid=3540918|work=[[The New Zealand Herald]]|date=December 2003|accessdate=1 November 2011|author=Rae, Fiona|publisher=[[APN News & Media]]}}{{cite web|title=Who killed Geoff Greenlaw? |url=http://tvnz.co.nz/view/tv2_minisite_story_skin/429383?format=html |work=[[Television New Zealand]] |year=2005 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121014094717/http://tvnz.co.nz/view/tv2_minisite_story_skin/429383?format=html |archivedate=14 October 2012 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Dom flees when Delphi confronts him about the murder but later returns, with Cortese suggesting it was for love; "But the thing about Dominic is he believes he's doing everything for the right reasons. He's done everything he can for Delphi — that's his main reason for coming back." Dom later scares Delphi into fleeing the country, ending the once seemingly perfect relationship. ==Reception== [[Michael Galvin]] listed the storyline between [[Chris Warner|Chris]] and Dom as one of the most iconic storylines on the soap.{{cite news|title=Dr Warner's case book|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/television/news/article.cfm?c_id=339&objectid=10513003|work=[[The New Zealand Herald]]|publisher=[[APN News & Media]]|date=30 May 2008|author=Hunkin, Joanna}} He believed his physical similarity with Cortese made the storyline more believable and captivating.{{cite web|title=Michael Galvin looks back on his favourite memories from Shortland Street|url=https://www.nowtolove.co.nz/celebrity/celeb-news/michael-galvin-looks-back-on-his-favourite-memories-from-shortland-street-32532|work=Now to Love|date=22 May 2017}} Rebecca Barry Hill of ''[[The New Zealand Herald]]'' noted the character of Dom as a highlight of the show.{{cite news|title=Shortland Street's drama queen|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/lifestyle/news/article.cfm?c_id=6&objectid=10384567|work=[[The New Zealand Herald]]|publisher=[[APN News & Media]]|date=1 June 2006|author=Barry Hill, Rebecca}} The storyline that saw Dom have an affair with 16-year-old [[Delphi Greenlaw|Delphi]] was viewed on as scandalous.{{cite web |title=Meet the man behind Evil Dom |work=[[Shortland Street]] |date=December 2004 |publisher=[[Television New Zealand]] |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6AlMhJ62U?url=http://tvnz.co.nz/view/tv2_minisite_story_skin/459806 |archivedate=18 September 2012 |url=http://tvnz.co.nz/view/tv2_minisite_story_skin/459806 |deadurl=yes |df= }} His return on the 3000th episode was described as "jaw dropping". The "Who Killed Geoff Greenlaw" storyline is remembered as hugely iconic. The characters stint proved to be a ratings success and the episodes which saw Dom return, be kidnapped by [[Bernadette Lucich|Bernadette]] and his death, proved to be the shows highest rating episodes for the year. Cortese himself however, believed he was "awful" in the role of Dom but enjoyed it nonetheless.{{cite news|title=Michele Hewitson interview: Shane Cortese|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/personalities/news/article.cfm?c_id=72&objectid=10757440|work=[[The New Zealand Herald]]|publisher=[[APN News & Media]]|date=8 October 2011|author=Hewitson, Michelle}} In 2012, the character was named as one of the standout characters of the show's first 20 years.{{cite journal|title=Shorty Superstars|journal=Shortland Street 20th anniversary magazine|publisher=[[APN News & Media|New Zealand Magazines]]|date=23 April 2012}} The storyline between Chris and Dom has been voted by fans as one of the most iconic moments on the show.{{cite web|title=Shorty: vote for your favourite moments|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/entertainment/blogs/on-the-box/6814211/Shorty-vote-for-your-favourite-moments|work=[[stuff.co.nz]]|publisher=[[Fairfax Media]]|date=27 March 2012|author=Philpot, Chris}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} {{Shortland Street}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Thompson, Dominic}} [[Category:Shortland Street characters]] [[Category:Fictional characters introduced in 2003]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2018}} {{spanish name|Ospina|Ramírez}} {{Infobox football biography | name = David Ospina | image = Policía de Infancia y Adolescencia - David Ospina (cropped).jpeg | image_size = 200 | caption = Ospina with [[Colombia national football team|Colombia]] in 2016 | fullname = David Ospina Ramírez<ref>{{cite web |url=https://tournament.fifadata.com/documents/FWC/2018/pdf/FWC_2018_SQUADLISTS.PDF |title=2018 FIFA World Cup Russia: List of players: Colombia |publisher=FIFA |format=PDF |page=5 |date=10 June 2018 |accessdate=11 June 2018}}</ref> | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1988|8|31|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Medellín]], Colombia | height = 1.83 m<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.premierleague.com/players/10420/David-Ospina/overview |title=David Ospina |date=2018 |publisher=Premier League |accessdate=23 March 2018}}</ref> | position = [[Goalkeeper (association football)|Goalkeeper]] | currentclub = [[S.S.C. Napoli|Napoli]] (on loan from [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]]) | clubnumber = 25 | youthyears1 = | youthclubs1 = [[Atlético Nacional]] | years1 = 2005–2008 | clubs1 = [[Atlético Nacional]] | caps1 = 97 | goals1 = 0 | years2 = 2008–2014 | clubs2 = [[OGC Nice|Nice]] | caps2 = 189 | goals2 = 0 | years3 = 2014– | clubs3 = [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] | caps3 = 29 | goals3 = 0 | years4 = 2018– | clubs4 = → [[S.S.C. Napoli|Napoli]] (loan) | caps4 = 10 | goals4 = 0 | nationalyears1 = 2005–2007 | nationalteam1 = [[Colombia national under-20 football team|Colombia U20]] | nationalcaps1 = 12 | nationalgoals1 = 0 | nationalyears2 = 2007– | nationalteam2 = [[Colombia national football team|Colombia]] | nationalcaps2 = 94 | nationalgoals2 = 0 | pcupdate = 08:02, 30 January 2019 (UTC) | ntupdate = 16 October 2018 | medaltemplates = {{Medal|Team|{{fb|COL}}}} {{Medal|B|[[Copa América Centenario]]|[[Copa América Centenario|2016]]}} }} '''David Ospina Ramírez''' ({{IPA-es|daˈβið osˈpina raˈmiɾes}}, born 31 August 1988) is a Colombian professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Goalkeeper (association football)|goalkeeper]] for [[Serie A]] club [[S.S.C. Napoli|Napoli]], on loan from {{English football updater|Arsenal}} club [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]], and the [[Colombia national football team|Colombia national team]].
Ospina began his career at [[Atlético Nacional]], making his debut with the club in 2005. After achieving two domestic titles with ''Los Verdolagas'', Ospina joined French side [[OGC Nice|Nice]]. In 2014, he joined [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] on a four-year deal.
Ospina has been representing his country at a full international level since 2007. Upon his debut against [[Uruguay national football team|Uruguay]], he became the second-youngest goalkeeper to play for Colombia. He has since earned over 90 caps for his nation and has appeared at three [[Copa América]]s and two [[FIFA World Cup|World Cups]].
==Club career== [[File:David Ospina.jpg|left|thumb|Ospina with Atlético Nacional in 2008]]
===Atlético Nacional=== Ospina began his professional career in [[Categoría Primera A]] club [[Atlético Nacional]] in 2005.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.fifa.com/world-match-centre/nationalleagues/nationalleague=england-premier-league-2000000000/news/newsid/240/835/0/index.html?intcmp=fifacom_hp_module_news |title=Arsenal seal Ospina signing |website=FIFA.com |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140808085405/http://www.fifa.com/world-match-centre/nationalleagues/nationalleague%3Dengland-premier-league-2000000000/news/newsid/240/835/0/index.html?intcmp=fifacom_hp_module_news |archivedate=8 August 2014}}</ref> Ospina played a total of 97 matches with the team, even being called to the national team. With the club, Ospina achieved three league titles. In mid-2008, Ospina was transferred to French club [[OGC Nice|Nice]].<ref name="Ospina to Nice">{{cite web|title=Ospina's transfer to Nice underway|url=http://www.goal.com/en-ie/news/3912/english-premier-league/2014/07/27/4973986/david-ospina-the-man-who-replaced-hugo-lloris-meet-the-new|publisher=Goal.com|accessdate=27 July 2014}}</ref>
===Nice=== [[File:Ospina1.JPG|thumb|right|Ospina playing for Nice]] After three seasons at [[Atlético Nacional]], at the age of 19, he was transferred to Nice in France for an undisclosed fee, believed to be about €2 million. Ospina was reportedly signed to become the long-term replacement of [[Hugo Lloris]], who had transferred to [[Olympique Lyonnais|Lyon]] for €8.5 million. However, Ospina was served as a substitute of [[Lionel Letizi]] for the first few months of his career, before breaking into the first team. [[Frédéric Antonetti]], the manager of Nice who brought Ospina to the club, said, "He has everything you need to be a top goalkeeper. He's good in the air and he's good on the ground. He has that little extra something to be a champion. Hugo Lloris was an international-standard goalkeeper; so is David."<ref name="Ospina Praised by Nice boss">{{cite web|title=Ospina will be a success|url=http://www.goal.com/en-ie/news/3912/english-premier-league/2014/07/27/4973986/david-ospina-the-man-who-replaced-hugo-lloris-meet-the-new|publisher=Goal.com|accessdate=27 July 2014}}</ref>
Four years into his career at Nice, Ospina publicly voiced his desire to leave the club. Nice coach [[Claude Puel]] signed promising young French goalkeeper [[Joris Delle]], and announced Delle would be promoted into the first team, sharing the position with Ospina. In the summer of 2012, Turkish club [[Besiktas J.K.|Besiktas]] attempted to sign Ospina,<ref name="Besiktas bid for Ospina fails">{{cite web|title=Ospina to Beskitas off|url=http://uk.eurosport.yahoo.com/news/nice-call-ospina-besiktas-sale-142023974.html|publisher=Yahoo.com|accessdate=1 August 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131203112050/http://uk.eurosport.yahoo.com/news/nice-call-ospina-besiktas-sale-142023974.html|archivedate=3 December 2013|df=}}</ref> however the move fell through.<ref name="Ospina is dropped">{{cite web|title=Ospina filled with frustration as he is club No 2|url=http://www.goal.com/en-ie/news/3912/english-premier-league/2014/07/27/4973986/david-ospina-the-man-who-replaced-hugo-lloris-meet-the-new|publisher=Goal.com|accessdate=27 July 2014}}</ref>
After Ospina's performances at the [[2014 FIFA World Cup|2014 World Cup]] and his rejection of a contract extension, he was linked to many European sides.<ref name="Ospina rejects contract">{{cite web|title=Ospina could leave for free next season after rejecting extension|url=http://www.getfootballnewsfrance.com/2014/david-ospina-set-to-walk-away-from-les-aiglons-for-free/|publisher=Obtenir le football|accessdate= 31 May 2014}}</ref> Despite being heavily linked to [[Atlético Madrid]], Puel announced that Ospina would depart the club to join English side [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]].<ref name="Ospina will join Arsenal">{{cite web|title=Puel: Ospina to Arsenal is done|url=http://www.101greatgoals.com/blog/nice-manager-claude-puel-confirms-david-ospina-has-joined-arsenal/|publisher=101greatgoals.com|accessdate= 27 July 2014}}</ref>
===Arsenal=== ====2014–15 season==== On 27 July 2014, Arsenal had confirmed that Ospina had signed for the club on for an undisclosed fee, believed to be £3 million, on a four-year deal.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/28508854|title=David Ospina: Arsenal sign Colombia goalkeeper from Nice|publisher=BBC Sport|date=27 July 2014|accessdate=29 July 2014}}</ref> Through the club's official [[Instagram]] account, Arsenal revealed that Ospina would wear the number 13 shirt for the club, last worn by loanee [[Emiliano Viviano]]. On 23 September 2014, Ospina made his debut for Arsenal in the [[2014–15 Football League Cup|League Cup]] match against [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]], a 2–1 home defeat.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.arsenal.com/match/report/1415/post/first-team/arsenal-v-southampton-match-report |title=Arsenal v. Southampton Match Report |work=Arsenal FC |date=23 September 2014 |accessdate=1 October 2014 }}</ref> He made his second Arsenal appearance on 1 October in their [[2014–15 UEFA Champions League|UEFA Champions League]] group stage match at home to [[Galatasaray S.K. (football)|Galatasaray]], replacing [[Alexis Sánchez]] after starting goalkeeper [[Wojciech Szczęsny]] had been sent off for a [[professional foul]] on [[Burak Yılmaz]]. Ospina conceded the penalty, taken by its earner, but Arsenal won 4–1, making several vital saves in the process.<ref>{{cite news|title=Arsenal 4–1 Galatasaray|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/29362640|accessdate=1 October 2014|work=BBC Sport|date=1 October 2014}}</ref> In October, Ospina suffered a thigh injury that would keep him out effectively for the rest of the 2014 calendar year.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.espnfc.com/arsenal/story/2102243/arsenals-david-ospina-ruled-out-for-around-three-months-with-thigh-injury|title=Arsenal's David Ospina ruled out for around three months with thigh injury|publisher=}}</ref> Ospina resumed his cup duties in a 2–0 win against [[Hull City A.F.C.|Hull City]], but maintained his place for his full [[Premier League]] debut a week later, keeping a clean sheet in a 3–0 win against [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke City]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.express.co.uk/sport/football/551394/Arsene-Wenger-Wojciech-Szczesny-team-selection|title=Arsene Wenger: Why I picked David Ospina instead of Wojciech Szczesny|date=11 January 2015|work=Daily Express}}</ref> With first-choice goalkeeper Szczęsny punished for smoking in the dressing room after a game against Southampton, Ospina was made first choice in the league and went on to claim successive clean sheets against [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] and [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]]. He played every remaining league game until the end of the season, with the exception of [[FA Cup]] ties against [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton & Hove Albion]], [[Middlesbrough F.C.|Middlesbrough]], [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] and [[Reading F.C.|Reading]]. Moreover, he was also an unused substitute in Arsenal's 4–0 win in the [[2015 FA Cup Final]] against Aston Villa.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/live/football/32563518|title=FA Cup final – FT: Arsenal 4–0 Villa|date=30 May 2015|work=BBC}}</ref> However, Ospina's performances earned him a place on the [[FIFA Ballon d'Or]] longlist for the [[2015 FIFA Ballon d'Or#FIFA Ballon d'Or|2015 campaign]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.gazzettaworld.com/off-the-ball/ospina-reacts-ballon-or/?refresh_ce-cp|title=Arsenal's Ospina reacts to Ballon d'Or selection|website=La Gazzetta dello Sport|accessdate=18 July 2016|date=3 October 2015|last=Sylla|first=Ogo}}</ref>
====2015–16 season==== [[File:David Ospina, 2015-05-31.JPG|left|thumb|Ospina after winning the [[2014–15 FA Cup|FA Cup]] with Arsenal in 2015]] During the summer transfer window period, Ospina was linked to [[Beşiktaş J.K.|Beşiktaş]] and [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] after Arsenal had signed [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] goalkeeper [[Petr Čech]], which effectively demoted Ospina to second-choice keeper. However, no deal materialised, as second-choice Wojciech Szczęsny was loaned to [[A.S. Roma|Roma]] for the season.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/33672118|title=Wojciech Szczesny: Arsenal keeper joins Roma on a season-loan deal|date=29 July 2015|work=BBC}}</ref> Ospina made his first appearance of the season in a 2–1 away defeat against [[GNK Dinamo Zagreb|Dinamo Zagreb]] in the [[2015–16 UEFA Champions League|2015–16 Champions League]],<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/34160767|title=Dinamo Zagreb 2–1 Arsenal|date=16 September 2015|work=BBC}}</ref> and as the team's "cup goalkeeper", he made his first domestic appearance in a 2–1 [[2015–16 Football League Cup|League Cup]] win over [[London]] [[North London derby|rivals]] [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/34265590|title=Tottenham 1–2 Arsenal|date=23 September 2015|work=BBC}}</ref> Ospina made another Champions League appearance, against [[Olympiacos F.C.|Olympiacos]], where his poor performances proved costly in a 3–2 home defeat, with the keeper conceding an own goal by dropping a corner from [[Kostas Fortounis]] into his own net'.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/34382802|title=Arsenal 2–3 Olympiakos|date=29 September 2015|work=BBC}}</ref> Ospina would later be dropped from Champions League duties in place of Čech. Ospina suffered a shoulder injury during October's international break that saw him ruled out until November. He was then in contention to face [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] in the [[2015–16 FA Cup|FA Cup]] in January, but a training injury saw Čech take his place.
====2016–17 season==== Ospina made his first start for Arsenal of the 2016–17 season in the club's opening game in the [[2016–17 UEFA Champions League|UEFA Champions League]] Group-stage against French champions [[Paris Saint Germain]], producing a man-of-the-match performance as Arsenal drew 1–1; Ospina himself drew praise for many saves made during the game, mainly against striker [[Edinson Cavani]]. Ospina started in the FA cup final where he conceded 1 goal as Arsenal won 2–1.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/37331259|title=Paris St-Germain 1–1 Arsenal|date=13 September 2016|website=Bbc.co.uk}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-3787688/PSG-1-1-Arsenal-Alexis-Sanchez-rescues-Champions-League-point-Gunners.html|title=PSG 1–1 Arsenal: Alexis Sanchez rescues Champions League point|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.uefa.com/uefachampionsleague/news/newsid=2403638.html|title=Ospina keen to seize chance after Arsenal heroics|first=|last=UEFA.com|publisher=}}</ref>
====2017–18 season==== Ospina made his first appearance of the season in a 1–0 win over [[Doncaster Rovers]] in the [[Carabao Cup]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/41249728|title=Arsenal 1–0 Doncaster|publisher=BBC Sport|date=20 September 2017|accessdate=3 October 2017}}</ref> He made his second start in a 3–1 [[Europa League]] win against [[FC Cologne]], committing an error that led to the team going 1–0 down early on.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/41227374|title=Arsenal 3–1 FC Cologne|publisher=BBC Sport|date=14 September 2017|accessdate=3 October 2017}}</ref> After Arsenal suffered four straight defeats Ospina kept a clean sheet as the Gunners beat [[AC Milan]] 2–0 at the [[San Siro Stadium]] in the Europa League round of 16 on 8 March.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/43321163|title=AC Milan 0–2 Arsenal|publisher=BBC Sport|date=8 March 2018|accessdate=11 March 2018}}</ref>
===Napoli (loan)=== Following the arrival of [[Bernd Leno]], Ospina requested go on loan in order to gain proper playing time. On August 15, Serie A team [[S.S.C. Napoli|Napoli]] agreed to a one-year loan deal with an option to buy following new signing [[Alex Meret]]'s injury.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/aug/15/david-ospina-joins-napoli-on-loan-from-arsenal |title= David Ospina joins Napoli on loan deal from Arsenal |newspaper=The Guardian |first1=Fabrizio |last1=Romano |first2=Sachin |last2=Nakrani |date=15 August 2018 |accessdate=15 August 2018 }}</ref>
==International career== [[File:FWC 2018 - Round of 16 - COL v ENG - Photo 088.jpg|right|thumb|Ospina during the Round of 16 penalty shoot-out against England]] Ospina had his first international experience representing Colombia's [[Colombia national under-20 football team|under-20 team]].<ref>{{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/*/http://es.fifa.com/tournaments/archive/tournament=104/edition=9102/teams/team=44021.html |date=* |title=2005 FIFA U-20 World Cup – Colombia squad }}</ref> Ospina was called up for the first time in the national U-20 team for [[2005 FIFA World Youth Championship]]. At only 16 years old, Ospina was the youngest member of the squad, however he did not play any game during the whole tournament. Ospina was called back for the [[2007 South American U-20 Championship]], where he played four games. However, Colombia failed to qualify for the World Cup, the last youth tournament he had the opportunity to play in.
Ospina made his debut for the senior team as a substitute in the 1–3 defeat against [[Uruguay national football team|Uruguay]]. He played his first match in a [[2010 FIFA World Cup qualification]] match against [[Bolivia national football team|Bolivia]], becoming the second-youngest goalkeeper to play for the Colombian national team.
Ospina was selected as the main goalkeeper for Colombia throughout the [[2014 FIFA World Cup qualification]] competition. At the end of the qualifiers, Ospina conceded the fewest number of goals of the tournament.
At the [[2014 World Cup]], Ospina appeared in all of Colombia's matches and conceded four goals throughout the tournament.
In May 2018 he was named in Colombia’s preliminary 35 man [[Colombia national football team|squad]] for the [[2018 World Cup]] in [[Russia]].<ref>http://www.goal.com/en-gb/amp/news/revealed-every-world-cup-2018-squad-23-man-preliminary-lists/oa0atsduflsv1nsf6oqk576rb</ref> Despite saving a penalty against [[Jordan Henderson]] in the Round of 16 penalty shoot-out against [[England national football team|England]], Colombia were eliminated 3–4 on penalties.
==Personal life== Ospina was brother-in-law to fellow Colombian international footballer [[James Rodríguez]], who married David's sister Daniela in 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://fabwags.com/?p=26880 |title=James Rodriguez The Soccer Star is also a Family Man |date=20 June 2014 |accessdate=15 June 2014}}</ref> However, they announced their separation in July 2017.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.goal.com/en/news/james-rod/1mugl77wy9d541exdz6rcd0eqt|title=James Rodriguez and wife Daniela Ospina announce separation |website=Goal.com|accessdate=9 June 2018}}</ref> Ospina is married to Colombian model Jesica Sterling, whom he married in 2012, and has one daughter named Dulce María <ref>{{cite news |url=http://fabwags.com/jesica-sterling-colombian-soccer-player-david-ospinas-wife/|work= Fabwags|date=9 September 2014 |title=Jesica Sterling – Colombian Soccer player David Ospina's Wife|accessdate=30 March 2015}}</ref> and a son named Maximiliano.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.goal.com/es-co/news/4604/colombianos-en-inglaterra/2015/01/26/8340492/david-ospina-es-padre-por-segunda-vez |title=David Ospina es padre por segunda vez |language=Spanish |date=26 January 2015 |website=Goal.com}}</ref>
